The pathologist rings to say the bruise on the wrist is a shy thing that cannot quite decide what it wants to be when it grows up. It is small and oblong and in the place where watch straps pinch if a hand is snatched without courtesy, which is not proof but is a story a person can tell themselves about a last carefulness that became an indignity. He says there is nothing of hand on mouth and nothing of knee in a bad place and nothing that demands anyone be led away for a dramatic conversation with the custody desk. He says also that hearts are manufactories and they stop without warning when components get old under fluorescent lights, and that is not poetry and not not-poetry either.

They go and see Chair Yoga because the day has decided to be themed. The hall smells like tea and dust as if it has been faithful to an era longer than any of its users, and a row of women in cardigans that resemble clouds are doing very small things with their spines while a voice tells them they are doing magnificently. The instructor is younger than the women and older than the girls who will replace her, and she has the patience of someone who has watched people be furious with their own backs and forgiven them for it. She remembers Marion because Marion said the chair was a friend who had become boring and she was trying to be kind to a boring friend. She remembers Marion wearing the watch and tapping its face as if intimidating time into agreeing to behave, and she remembers no gutters man in that hour because the hall has a noticeboard where such men leave their leaflets, and she personally rips them down and gives them to the school for cutting out because the children do not care for scams yet. She knows Wendy because of course she does and she says of Wendy that she is a good weather system in a cold room.

At the Meeting House Ken is holding a one-to-one with a man who looks like a wardrobe whose shelves are overloaded, and he catches Owen’s eye in the way of someone who would like to be seen to be helpful. They speak alleys and gutters with the shorthand of two people who have become temporary colleagues in a theatre where neither of them owns the stage. Ken tells him that three of his old ladies have had visitors lately with talk of water damage that is less about water and more about entering. He says he wrote down a plate number badly because he does his best thinking in loops and straight lines frighten him, and he offers the paper in his pocket that has two possible eights and a five that could be an S. There’s a small satisfaction in being the recipient of someone else’s care, even if it is chaotic care, and Owen takes the paper as if it is a guinea pig.

Silas is not at the yard and not in the places where he likes to be seen being not, and when Owen does catch him he is on the river path doing nothing with his arms, which for Silas is a performance. They walk side by side as if it had been arranged and avoid looking like they are avoiding the looking. Owen mentions the gutter men and Rook sucks his teeth because he hates amateurs who think a disguise is a fluorescent jacket. He says there is a cousin-cousin with a van who does legitimate roof work and an illegitimate tendency to let his friends borrow credibility in exchange for forever owing him sausages. He says he will ask without making it look like a policeman asked through him and he will report back whether there is any love in that lineage. He says the thing about watches is not time, it is that they are small and gold-looking and a certain kind of boy thinks that makes them coins with faces. He says he will return to Ken to be told to slow down his jaw and he will consider chewing each mouthful for a county-approved number of times and he will probably lie and reduce it by three.

The pawnshop rings just before five and the man with the glasses that do not get excited twice says the beard has returned and is now calling itself Gary because Dave is a name that gets used up quickly in these types. He says the watch is now in a different pocket and the beard has learned to say his girlfriend gave it to him, which is a sentence that is supposed to plug moral holes and somehow never once has. They go and the beard is the sort of beard that has become a shelter for a face that wants to be older, and the man attached to it has the twitchy kindness of a person who will apologise even when he has been robbed. He says he found the watch under a bench in Goodlands Park while throwing a ball for a dog with one ear and he says this too quickly for belief to be an option. He introduces the dog’s name as if that helps and the dog is called Nigel, which is either a lie so grand it deserves applause or proof there is a God of small comic touches.

They take the watch and the man because evidence must be accompanied by a narrative, and the back of the watch says To M, time keeps us honest and the date is a summer from before whoever you are was born. Laura comes to the station because someone should be the person who says oh and then yes and then something untranslatable, and she holds the watch like it is both a crime scene and a photograph. The relief on her face is difficult even to be near because it disguises two other feelings as itself, fear and guilt, and Owen watches her swallow and wants the moment to pass only because it would be indecent to stand there and make a snack of it. She says she will keep it and he says keep it until we say differently and she nods with that dazed compliance good people have when the systems that take days from them also sometimes return a thing.

There is a list in the office now with a heading written in a hand Maeve uses when she has decided she will not be ashamed of her own neatness: DOOR MEN. Beneath are notes that could belong to a school play if they didn’t matter. Van possibly white. Plate possibly two 8s. Jackets that glow like a hazard conceived by an accountant. No logo or logo you can peel off. Patience limited by weather. They add to it as the hours present new fragments; Mr. Kettle texted to say Elsie had a caller who offered to check batteries in smoke alarms, which is a new script that needs rehearsing. Ken sent an email with three bullet points though Owen does not approve of bullet points in principle: trust your doubt, ask for ID, ring a number you already know. Griggs passes the room, reads the list, and makes a face like he has bitten a grape that presented as sweet and turned herbal. He says good and then ruins it by asking if the watch is going to come with an alibi and then adds that he expects the press to want to commemorate the retrieved sentiment out of all proportion to its utility.

That night Owen goes to Katie’s because he is carrying the residue of everybody’s afternoon and some rooms are good at taking residue and turning it back into air. She has an evening class for small hands, which comes with a kind of noise he tires of and misses in the same breath, and she moves through the room with an attention that is the exact width of each person’s day. Ro is there because Min cannot say no to a boy with a new word in his pocket and the word today is structure, which he likes because it is both a thing you can touch and a thing you can pretend to understand. They make flowers that have little paper insects tucked between petals because this is how happiness hides, and Ro tells him he has written a story where a bee hides in a rose because the bee is frightened of being famous, and Owen says remind me never to be your bee because I would not survive the attention, and Ro says it is fine, the bee gets to go to Minehead and have a look at the edge.

They talk about nothing and everything, the way you do when doing with your hands frees your mouth from proving it is clever. Katie tells him about a customer who asked for a sympathy bouquet that wasn’t funereal because she wanted the room to feel like an apology rather than a wake, and she tells him about glue brands as if brands are football teams, and she tells him about having burned her finger again because some people’s competence is professional and their humanity is clumsy and both are required in a room. He tells her about the watch and about Goodlands Park and Nigel the one-eared liar and she laughs with the sort of laughter that is relief performing a waltz. He doesn’t tell her about the bruise because he does not want to give her wrists a story they will then carry for two days.

On the way home he passes the bus station again because it has become almost a route he trusts even when the town bends. Aiden is not there because a good day for Aiden would mean he is where he said he would be, and Owen lets himself believe in good days because his job only costs him entirely when he forgets they exist. Outside the Castle Hotel a couple argue quietly in the careful tones of polite society who have mislaid their poise, and a man in a long coat that is not a choice stands in the doorway and smokes in a way that says he would quite like to be a better version of himself and is waiting to be given permission. A gull does the noise that will not be improved upon by any God and a small group of teenagers decide to pretend they are not cold as the evening throws down its mildness like a damp towel.

He sleeps in a way that would not pass assessment and wakes too early, which is a habit he has broken and resumed more times than he has visited the optician. He walks to his window and the river is available but refuses to be about him still, which is what he pays it for, and the lights hold the bridge like jewellery and the jogger who passes is one of those men who runs like he is smiling and Owen forgives him for it. In the kitchen he peels the sticker off a new pack of tissue paper with ceremonial slowness because nobody is going to give him a ribbon to cut and yet rituals help, and he folds until the part of his mind that writes sentences about risk and harm is tired enough to sleep again. He makes two leaves that are finally cousins and not strangers and he places them next to the peony that has become the week’s lit candle.

The next day begins with a van stop because sometimes coincidence will reward you if you kick it in the shins. Pond calls from Roman Road with a voice that belongs in a slightly older policeman and says we have a van that is either white or it would be if it was not acquainted with rural life and a plate that has more eights than is strictly beautiful. They go and the van is what vans are—a mess of paperwork that is never what you want and sandwich remains—and the two men inside are versions of a man that a town like this produces when it wants doorways to have to work harder. They do the polite work and then the unapologetic work and there are clipboards that do not have logos and leaflets that say things illiterate printers have made uglier. The men are wearing the expression of people who consider their job to be a kind of service and the universe to be their consenting customer.

The worry is that this is not dramatic enough to be a plot and dramatic enough to bruise a week. They take details that will be misremembered and bettered in the retelling and they tell the men to stop doing the thing they are doing and the men say what thing is that and they say the thing with old women who would like to die without being talked at by people with fake safety vests. They issue the piece of paper that carries what little it can carry and they watch the men become the kind of angry that is mostly relieved at being told by someone in a proper coat to stop rehearsing being a wolf. When they return to the station there is the peculiar satisfaction of having made a small dent in a hallway of dents, and there is the familiar irritation of having to write it down without being able to say we did a thing that counts, we might have stopped a bruise.

By the end of the week, Marion’s watch has a chain of custody that would satisfy a pedant and a small parade of people have put their head round the station door to say a sentence that begins with at least, as if they have been deputised by hope to do post. The bruise remains noncommittal and the peony remains evidence of nothing but a world where kindness and glue share a shelf. Griggs gives them a noise that, for him, is encouraged and tells them to keep their eyes on Rook because Rook is a weather map printed in someone else’s ink. Maeve tells Owen to sleep and then tells him she knows he cannot because his eyes have that polished look, and she leaves a packet of crisps on his desk with a note that says for when the vending machine disrespects you.

On Saturday he goes to the class because he has promised his hands that if they do weekday duty they will be let off the leash for ninety minutes in a room where nothing has to be solved. The table is full of people who have discovered that folding is a form of prayer that allows blasphemy, and Katie has put a small jug of jonquils by the biscuits because she is not afraid to mix paper with real, as if to say they are friends. Greg is there and tells him about caulking with a seriousness that suggests caulking saved his life once, and Min listens to Ro explain photosynthesis to his own flower and nods like a scientist. They work and do the sort of talking that makes rooms safe; there is gossip about a hen night that required diplomatic intervention and there is a kindness left anonymously for someone whose dog is about to do the brave thing and there is one brief moment where a woman looks at nothing as if something has just left her, and Katie is in front of her with a cup before the group has even noticed.

At clean-up, whilst the tissue is being told off for being everywhere, Katie finds a scrap in the corner under the table that has been trodden into something resembling a message. It is a torn bit of a leaflet with only two letters and an arrow on it, and it can belong to any advert because arrows and letters are the lingua franca of people who put paper in public places. Still, Owen pockets it like a man who collects bits of luck in case the day needs topping up. He walks home in the kind of rain that does not consider itself rain and he thinks about watches and paper and the cost of breath. He catches his reflection in a charity shop window next to a row of orphaned dinner suits, and he pauses because the man in the glass looks like someone who has found a new corner in his own room. It is not joy. It is not sadness. It is the soft thing that sits between when you let it.

Sunday brings football on the County Ground and language in the street that believes itself only audible to the weather, and it brings a message from Mr. Kettle that he has decided to write K with his left hand forever because it slows him down and perhaps that is good medicine. It brings also a photograph from Ken of a whiteboard with the word boundary written and then circled and then circled again, and Owen laughs out loud and scares a pigeon into a sincerity it did not intend. He texts Maeve to say the boys with clipboards have been sat on and she asks if the dent left by their sitting is permanent, and he says nothing is, and she says that doesn’t make a case to my taste and then sends a picture of a pub roast with the caption officer down.

On Monday a call comes from Greenway Avenue, not from the house with the affronted chair but from next door where the lilac fleece lives. The woman in the fleece has a voice like a cardigan and she says there has been a man in the street with an argument and the argument was with either the world or a hedge, she could not tell which because both remained unresponsive. They go because arguments have a way of acquiring spectators and therefore plot, and find a man not young who is remonstrating with a bin as if it has betrayed his trust. He is wearing a tweed waistcoat that has seen rain and he smells like barley sugar and old tobacco and he is Kevin Kettle and he is, apparently, angry at the concept of waste collection schedules. He looks at Owen like a man who has been found mid-monologue and is mildly embarrassed. He says he has been experimenting with not swallowing all his feelings because Ken says you must sometimes give them little windows and he has decided to test the advice on a Thursday’s bin because the bin cannot be hurt. He laughs and says that perhaps he will choose a tree next time because bins draw crowds and he is too old to be beheld.

Owen stands with him and says he is proud of him for sparing the bin any more eloquence and Mr. Kettle says in a small voice that his hands shook on Friday and he does not know why and he would like to know why but not the sort of why that has a price tag. He says he has been alive a long time and does not want to reach the end and think that all his feelings were receipts he never read. Owen realizes, standing in that tidy street, that the watch has returned to its wrist, the peony has returned to a room as a thing and not a symbol, and the town is back to its fidgeting and its tiny tenderness and its always-almost disasters. He realizes also that the case is not closed because cases never are, they are only moved to a shelf where they can look at other cases and nod politely.

He goes back to the station and puts a note in the file that says the watch was found and the bruise remains undecided and the gutter men are being discouraged with legal paper and volume, and he writes a line to remind himself later that what mattered was not whether a peony is evidence but that it was a thing people held onto when the room was a bit too much. On his desk, the paper flower looks less ridiculous than it did and more like a standard he has chosen to carry. He writes a message to Katie to say that if she needs wire he knows a yard where the man selling it will pretend not to be generous and the boy measuring it will be learning the names of trees from the ends of splinters. She replies with a picture of a ribbon misbehaving on purpose and he feels the peculiar satisfaction of being included in someone else’s inventory of small victories.

Silas appears at four without fanfare because even he has days when he does not need an entrance, and he leans on the corner of the desk until Griggs gives him a look that would peel paint. He says the cousin-cousin with the van has been told to stop lending credibility to people with clipboards because credibility is the only currency he has left that isn’t counterfeit. He says he has found something at the river, and he produces from his pocket an object wrapped in a piece of his own shirt because theatre might be silly and also why waste an opportunity. It is a watch strap, not a watch, the leather chewed by water into something that would consider being a fish. He says it was snagged on a hook near the low bridge and it could belong to anybody and he thought of Owen because he is merciless to himself and mercy for others is something he is trying under adult supervision.

Owen takes the strap and he thinks of the park and Nigel and the way objects get lost in a town like this by moving not far and by people who know the wrongness of their own hands and want not to. He logs it and labels it and gives it a number that will not flinch and thanks Silas in a tone that is not a truce but is not not a truce. Silas smiles like an abandoned pier being flattered by the tide and says he will bring biscuit donations to Ken because Ken’s biscuits are ambitious but not quite generous enough, and he leaves with that small satisfying spin that means he would like the last image of him to be of a man who can be claimed for goodness at least once a week.

At shift’s end, Owen goes to the river and leans because leaning is a vice he can defend in court. The peony is at home and he misses it in the pocket of his coat like a talisman he keeps telling himself is just paper. He watches a swan do that thing swans do where they pretend to be ballet and actually they are knives with feathers, and he listens to the town clear its throat for evening. Somewhere, in a room with shut curtains, a woman is writing down the names of the people who came when she asked for help and the names of the people who came when she didn’t, and she is deciding she prefers the second list. Somewhere, in the salvage yard, Aiden is learning to distinguish oak from ash by its weight as if the world were a person you could know by how they sit on your lap. Somewhere, in a back room that smells of tissue and tea, Katie is counting ribbon by hand and letting herself cheat on three because she is human and so are we.

He goes home and opens his window with the caution he has for objects that have decided to be in his care, and he sits at his table and makes a peony that is less showy than the first and more like something that would last in a room which has had to learn the trick of lasting. He thinks not in conclusions because they don’t trust him, but in the good half-thoughts that later become a way of being. He thinks that sometimes a bruise is a comma and not a full stop. He thinks that sometimes a watch goes on a small tour of the town and returns in time for the sentence to make sense. He thinks that sometimes paper is a truth because it remembers the hands that made it, and he thinks that if he is going to continue to be the sort of man who knocks on doors and collects other people’s nights in trays, then he had better also continue to be the sort of man who sits quietly and folds, and lets the room be a room and not a report. He thinks this and then lets the thought be boring on purpose, because boredom is rest dressed as something else, and he puts down the scissors and eats toast and answers Maeve’s text with a photograph of the flower on the table and the words: chief superintendent of tissue reporting a small, unimportant success, over.Chapter Seven

Market day arrives with a fuss and then pretends it didn’t make one. The tents go up along Fore Street like bright little arguments, the tarpaulins shivering at the idea of rain, the air already scented with onions learning to be burgers and coffee that has ambitions it may or may not fulfil. Owen stands by the station window with his coat half on and watches the traders lay out the objects that will, for a handful of hours, be the town’s priorities. There is a stall of wools in improbable sherbets, another of tools that look like they were born to outlive men, and a table covered in old crockery that someone will call vintage because it is nicer to lie if the lie is pretty. He thinks that somewhere in this street there will be a watch that once belonged to someone else, and he tells his head that we are done with watches, we have done what we can for watches, and then his hands put themselves in his pockets because they do not trust him not to go looking anyway.

Maeve arrives with a pastry she insists is medicinal and a face that is pretending to disapprove of weekends. She drops into the chair opposite with the neat collapse of a gymnast who only displays it when nobody is asking for it and pushes the pastry at him as if it has offended her. “Griggs is vibrating,” she says. “Trading Standards want a hand with the door-to-door men, and he says words like joint operation as if he is asking us to marry a bureaucracy. Also, I promised my nephew I’d get him a knock-off football shirt that will disintegrate the second it sees a washing machine, and I don’t want to die in prison for complicity.”

“He’ll make you go to court for wearing trainers,” Owen says, taking a bite of the pastry and trying not to grimace at the sugar deciding to be his entire mouth. “What’s our pitch to the clipboard men.”

“Hello, we too have clipboards,” she says, and taps her temple with a pencil. “We’re to be visible without frightening the elderly into not making tea. Smile, but only with the top half of your face, and try to look like a leaflet. And then,” she adds, leaning in because if a thing is said leaning in it becomes something else, “Katie’s doing a stall outside Paper & Thread for the workshop—Mother’s Day prequel—and I said we could hover. Community reassurance. Also, she said she’s got new wire and I want to see what new wire looks like when you’ve been burgled for old wire.”

“New wire looks like a promise,” Owen says, and Maeve, who spots his soft sentences and saves them for blackmail, raises an eyebrow and lets it pass without harvesting. She has patience for the little enthusiasms he has chosen; she has a list of them in her head and she keeps it to herself like a child’s pocket collection of good stones.

Griggs does indeed vibrate. He does it by changing the colour of the word urgent in his voice and then pretending he didn’t. He stands in the briefing room next to a blown-up photograph of a fluorescent jacket with no logo, and he points at it like a man introducing a relative he would rather not have to acknowledge. “We share this town with opportunists,” he says, and at opportunists his lip does a small and involuntary curl as if he has bitten lemon. “If they knock and talk, you knock and talk louder. I don’t want to read on Facebook that a man in a hat with a pen defeated the Queen of Taunton with chat. Trading Standards, TS to their mates, will say their bit about cold calling zones. We will not roll our eyes where they can see us. We will, as ever, be professional.”

The map of the town on the wall is beginning to look to Owen like a board game invented by someone who was very fond of rules and rather less fond of fun. He traces, without moving, the route from the salvage yard to the Meeting House to Paper & Thread to Greenway Avenue and back to the station, and it draws an untidy heart he will not name. He and Maeve go out into the market and let the noise of buying things that may not be required do the blanket thing to the background anxieties of the week, and for a small set of minutes he lets himself be the kind of stranger who drinks a paper cup of coffee and nods at a dog carrier full of knitted hats. He sees Mr. Kettle long before Mr. Kettle sees him because Mr. Kettle is at a stall offering old postcards of seaside towns, and he is giving an impromptu lecture on the ethics of hand-tinting to a teenager who is politely pretending to be interested and who will later buy one to prove to himself he is kind.

Paper & Thread has come out to meet the day. The sandwich board promises paper peonies with the encouragement of a midwife, and Katie has a table under a small tent the colour of childhood dresses. The tissue is stacked like a sweetshop and the wire is coiled into neat little crowns, and there are three finished blooms for show that look impossible enough to begin conversations. Katie is in a jumper that is the blue of tins on good shelves and her hair has formed a compromise with itself that manages to look intentional. She sees Owen and then registers the badge and smooths her face into the I-know-where-we-are smile that small business owners develop to survive both the public and officialdom, and then she remembers herself and does her other smile, which is a thing she gives her chosen people.

“You look like PC Plod’s handsome cousin,” she says, lightly, and he blushes because he is not used to handsome being used anywhere near his vicinity unless it is in a joke about antique furniture. “Staying?”

“Hovering,” he says. “Official hovering. Supportive presence slash threat to pickpockets.”

“I can work with that,” she says. “I’ll sell peonies and you sell the idea of moral improvement.”

Mr. Kettle ambles over with the quickness of a man who has seen three diversions and chosen the fourth. He has a tweed waistcoat on because of course he does, and his beard is a tidy compromise with his age. He brings with him the smell of barley sugar out of habit, and he produces from his pocket without fanfare three wrapped sweets as if he is paying a toll. “Officer Tissue,” he says to Owen with a tiny bow, and to Katie he offers his hands for ribbon duty like a man approaching Communion. “I am to make something inadequate for a lady whose grandchildren have bought her an iPad,” he says. “I refuse to be bested by a rectangle. Give me wire, give me paper, give me a fight I can win.”

Ken Wright appears in the way of a man who has the timings of other people’s towns in his diary. He wears a jacket that has forgiven him for being Ken and a smile that is not the whole of his face, and he stands just outside the tent as if waiting to be asked for his opinion. He does his public-spirited thing where he buys a flower and then makes sure no one is watching when he produces a loyalty card for coffee, and for two minutes he is only a man making a morning look like a choice he has elected to make well. He tells Owen very quietly that he has given a talk to the WI about the dangers of believing men with laminated ID, and he says it with the tone of a man who expects a trophy and will happily accept a biscuit in its stead.

The butcher is where he always is at this time, arms folded, mouth set into a grin rueful enough to be used as seasoning. He calls across the road, “Sarge, are those real,” and Owen shouts back without using a shout that, no, they are made of the tears of social workers, and Katie chokes on a laugh so sudden she turns it into a cough. There is weather in the air like a rumour, and the gulls are being articulate about a chip two streets away, and the town is busy making the argument for itself without needing anyone to moderate.

The first thing goes wrong and it does not look like a thing going wrong because it is polite. A woman whose bag has a strap like a belt and a face like someone who has been kind for a long time reaches for her purse to pay for a bloom and finds that the purse is behaving like magic. It is not there, and it is not anywhere, and the moment makes a very small silence around her, a circle of suddenly uncooperative air. She says, lightly, that she is an idiot and then more quietly that she had it at the cake stall and then she describes the purse to Owen as if it is an old friend who has run off with a stranger. He and Maeve do the little triangle dance of police in a crowd, the one that says we are here and not here, and they exchange a look that says we are back to theft when we wanted to be at craft.

Ro is along the edge of the stall with Min, his fingers investigating a length of wire as if it has a song. He is doing that pre-adolescent thing where his attention could feed a city and you can watch the moment when it narrows into sense. “Hat man,” he says, not looking up, and points with his chin. “Same as pawnshop? Beard like he’s hiding a biscuit. Brown hat that doesn’t like his head. He is practicing being not noticed.”

The beard that called itself Dave and then Gary is browsing the mugs two stalls down, and browsing is too generous because his eyes do not rest anywhere long enough to describe having enjoyed resting. He has a brown felt hat that makes him look worse, which is an achievement, and his jacket is the colour of compromise. His hands are the wrong kind of careful. When his eyes pass over Owen you can see the instinct to be pleasant, to be charming, to be the sort of person men shake hands with in pubs, and you can see the calculation that says that this particular target has read that book and returns it with annotations.

Owen doesn’t give chase because there is nothing to chase yet and because he has learned the economies of movement available to him. He lets the crowd take him and he slides sideways into the wake of the man whose aliases have all begun to resemble each other. He hears behind him the smooth, unrelated conversations of a town on a Saturday morning—someone wanting peas without the peas, someone else making hard weather of a simple technical matter—and he lets the sound be there while his eyes do their job. The man with the hat does the thing where he looks in a shop window without seeing anything behind the glass and then makes a decision that looks like indecision. He turns toward the multi-storey like a man who has considered walking to the moon and settled for the level just below the roof of Sainsbury’s.

Up in the car park the air has a different temperature, a sort of concrete weariness, and the man’s hat looks suddenly like theatre in a foyer where no one is yet seated. He slows, which is either fatigue or performance, and then he bends to tie an already tied shoe, which is the move thieves learned in the year nineteen whenever and have been loyal to ever since. Owen lets the distance be what it needs to be to make his voice arrive as if it has walked, and he says the man’s name as if it is a shared secret from another time. “Gary,” he says, and when the head comes up too quickly he says, “Or was it Dave. It changes for me as well. Do we need to pick a new one for you in front of a desk.”

“Found it,” the man says, as if they have just discovered a spoon under a sofa cushion and the whole of a complicated social exchange can be reset to kindly domestic irritation. He puts a hand in his inside pocket and produces a purse with the casual guilt of a child who knows the adult already knows. It is the right purse, of course it is, the little silver clip like a smile, and he holds it out as if he is donating it to a raffle. “I was going to hand it in,” he says, and then laughs at himself because the lie arrives late and tired and makes no difference to what happens next.

They do the talk on the stairwell because it is private enough and public enough and because the whole point is to make the man understand he is being treated as a person even as he is being treated as a man who will be, in about eleven minutes, asked to sit somewhere he does not want to sit. Owen uses the tone he saves for people who are not strangers to the idea that they are better than their day and he asks the questions that are less about catching and more about making a map. The watch is not on him, which would have been too neat, but there are two wallets, both of which are returned to their owners within half an hour in an exchange that feels like putting back a word in the right sentence. There is also wire in the boot of his car, which is the wrong kind of wire because it is new and clean and bought with intent. He says he was going to mend a trellis; he says his girlfriend likes roses; he says he has more than one girlfriend and all of them like roses; and he stops talking when he hears the footstep of a man arriving with paperwork in his pocket.

“Who are you working for today,” Owen asks, because men like this always are, and the answer comes with the rolled eyes of someone who thinks the hierarchy he belongs to is a joke even as it keeps him fed. “Blake,” he says, and then because he has had to tell the truth somewhere in a week for it to go down and this is his moment, “Two-Eights. He calls himself that. For the plate. For luck. He thinks the number eight is his mother. He thinks the council owes him a road.”

Two-Eights is the man in the white van with more eights than a reasonable plate ought to, and the satisfaction is small and present because it says the town is not reinventing its wolves every morning; it is borrowing them from the last night and changing the hats. Owen waits for the trade to show in the man’s face, the one that says what he will give and what he will keep, and he lets the arrest be untheatrical because dignity is both policy and, if he is honest, a superstition. In the market below, life continues to sell itself, which is the most reassuring and least comforting fact he knows.

By the time he brings the purse back to the woman at the stall it has become a story she will tell with gratitude and a quiet embarrassment, and she tries to give him a five-pound note for his trouble as if this is a fairy tale, and he says please don’t because he has never known what to do with that kind of tender. Katie does the competent person’s magic lady act where she makes the only right words available to a person whose day has wrong in it. She tells the woman she has lovely hands and puts the flower aside as if it has a name and she will not sell it to anyone else, and she tucks a tag into the ribbon and for a second the market becomes a place where people are supervised by a kind god.

Something goes wrong again, in a different key. One of the finished flowers on the table disappears and is back and disappears and is back and then is not back, and it is small but it hurts because things have been taken from this small room under a tent enough times, and Katie stands straighter because uprightness is resistance, and then it turns out to be a little girl with a fringe like a lawn and eyes that are prepared to cry, and she has been in possession of the peony for three minutes without understanding that possession can be complicated, and her father returns it with a clumsy speech about honesty, and Owen watches the exact moment when shame gets introduced into someone’s house and decides to be a door that opens rather than a wall that instructs. He gives the little girl a scrap of tissue and shows her a fold you can teach a person in thirty seconds that gives them ownership of their hand, and she looks at the crumpled thing as if it has given her back something she did not know she needed.

Midday is all edges. Trading Standards arrive in hi-vis that actually means something, and the clipboard men sidle off to be elsewhere, and Mr. Kettle completes the ribbon-pinning with the solemnity of a man performing dentistry on a doll. Ken does a round of handshakes as if he is running for a very small office and slips Owen a card that says boundary on it in his own careful handwriting, and then immediately asks if it was too much and if so he will withdraw the word. Maeve, who has a capacity for being useful while appearing to be entirely ornamental, does ten conversations at once, two of which are with dogs, and concludes that the town is in a mood to be told not to be careless without being told it is careless. The butcher sells a man sausages with the air of a priest distributing absolution, and a teenager practices a trick with a fidget spinner as if he intends to make it his trade.

Silas passes by with his gravity set to charming and makes a point of not seeing Owen until he has already been seen, and then he does a little bow like a man who has rehearsed grace. He buys a flower and takes a long time doing it and longs to be taken for a man who knows what to do with paper in the presence of a woman who knows what to do with paper, and he compliments the wire in a way that can be taken three ways. He has a boy at his shoulder who is not Aiden because the world is more generous in its malice than to repeat itself, and he gives the boy money he calls lunch rather than wages, and the boy looks like someone who has been paid for the first time and suspects the note will evaporate if he unfolds it in the wrong shop.

When the cake stall begins toothless gossip about the arrest up in the car park the air shifts in that way where the town remembers what it is supposed to do for itself. People are suddenly grateful for each other in principle, even if they are quite cross with each other in the detail, and somebody buys a bouquet they do not need and then remembers someone who might and takes it to them and by the end of the hour Katie’s box is half empty in the way boxes are ideally empty. Owen lets himself be pleased that his presence is part of the right theatre and not the wrong one, and he lets himself think, for three seconds, that perhaps it is possible to have a job that takes and a hobby that gives and let both swim in the same sea without making a killing.

Of course the day would not be the day without a small, good thing being spoiled. Halfway through a demonstration of the crease-friend trick something grabs the back of Owen’s arm through his coat and when he turns it is not danger but an urgency that looks like danger to someone who has not had to practice the difference. Laura Vale stands there with a face that has either cried or is about to and she is holding the watch at an angle that suggests she is afraid of damaging the time. “It’s not hers,” she says, and the sentence is an admission ticket into another hour. “The engraving—the date is right but the wear is wrong. I woke last night and I just knew. I took Mum’s jewellery box out of the drawer and I looked at pictures and I knew. I’m sorry. It is not hers.”

He takes the watch because he has to and because he wants to save her hands from the job they have taken on, and he registers the small quake in her voice that comes when a person has to unravel a relief they have prematurely laid on themselves. It is not the first time something has come back wrong in the shape of right and it will not be the last, and it is not anyone’s fault in particular and yet it will insist on making itself someone’s for the purposes of the person who wants to sleep tonight. He tells her they will take it back without letting go of the fact that the last week needed this to be neat and it is not going to be, and she presses her lips together as if to stop the word at least coming out and then says it anyway and then asks how you return a thing to the wrong sort of belonging.

Afternoon draws its own little borders. Trading Standards pack away their pop-up gravitas and leave leaflets about not letting men in no matter how persuasive their fluorescent vests, and the market gives up on itself in patches and then all at once as the stalls disassemble into the luckless shapes they are when not on duty. A child has lost a shoe and is laughing about it as if this is a win, and a man has bought a painting of a dog because the artist was disappointed in a way that required rescue, and a gull is making its case to be included in the general amnesty for nuisances. Katie counts the cash into the jar with the concentration of a person honouring the pact between honest work and honest reward, and between notes she checks her phone because a woman who runs a shop is in a permanent relationship with a device that lets the world tell her what it wants from her.

They take statements in the back room with the kettle doing its journey from hum to sing like a friend pretending a talent. The purse lady thanks them three times, each time for a different thing—the manner, the speed, the absence of contempt—and Owen files this away as if it will feed him when he has a day that does not. They give Gary/Dave to custody with the amicable sternness of teachers finally sending a boy to the head, and he goes with that mixture of relief and outrage that is the standard uniform of the temporarily caught. There will be a court and a story and there will be the attempt to make out of his day an aberration rather than a summary, and Owen will do his lines and not enjoy them and then he will go to the river and make himself into a person who can fold paper without the paper thinking he is occupying the room too loudly.

In the quiet after the quiet, between taking their coats off and deciding they have taken them off for the last time today, he and Maeve find themselves in the evidence store in front of a box that has not been kind enough to resolve into a utility. The door-to-door operation has a smell, and it is stress and cheap deodorant and sometimes private fear leaked into public space, and it clings. Maeve, who has a capacity for cruelty when it is kind, says, “You look like the market let you be a person,” and he says, “It did,” and then he adds, “Laura’s watch is not her watch,” and they both stand in the do-not-touch of what that requires. “We will find out who Nigel’s Nigel is,” she says. “We will talk to Two-Eights again and I will count that as a weekend activity.” She is writing a joke and a promise into the same sentence and the fact it works is the reason he will follow her into rooms until one of them forgets that you can come back out of them.

Ken’s email lands with his set of polite bullet points and a photograph of the whiteboard with boundary written and then improved by someone at the meeting to include the word porous in small letters underneath, and Owen laughs because the word makes him think of bread. He writes back thank you in a tone that is careful not to be either snide or wooed, and he closes his eyes in his chair for the kind of rest that could be legitimately described as blinking. When he opens them again there is a strip of late light on the floor in front of his boots like tape for an actor, and the station is full of the sounds of people convincing themselves they are nearing the end of something.

He goes to Paper & Thread because the day will sulk if he doesn’t. The shop has taken back its afternoon and looks as if it has inhaled, and Katie is elbow-deep in ribbon and triumph and minor grief and she has that look of someone who has been good all day and will now, if permitted, be silly. They stand on the floor among the shelves and talk about wire as if it is a moral choice and he holds the wrong watch in his palm and says too much and she edits it into the amount she can bear to own. She tells him she will teach him to do a centre that won’t sulk and he realises he has been waiting his whole week to be told to do something in that exact tone. She gives him three sheets of tissue in a colour that does not exist on glorified screens and a piece of ribbon that will not behave, and she says, “Take this home and make it misbehave correctly,” and he finds himself wanting to pass that instruction on to his job.

The text from Aiden arrives at the bus stop, a message that is both proud and tentative because boys are trained to be cautious with proud. Got paid, it says, and a picture of a fiver with a thumb in it, and then, as if covering his own joy with a blanket, still got to tell my mum I didn’t spend it. Owen writes back good boys tell their mums and brave boys do it badly and still do it, and Aiden replies with an emoji that he will later disavow because softness is a liability and a superpower and he is not yet able to hold those two facts in the same pocket.

That night, because not sleeping is a skill he has and he refuses to treat it as one, he puts the wrong watch on the table next to the flowers and he watches the hands agree to disagree with the hour. He takes the tissue and he makes a centre that does not sulk, not all at once and not beautifully, but he makes it, and he sits in the small room that making opens up and he stays there the length of a song he does not like, and then a silence he does. He thinks of Silas pretending not to improve, of Ken pretending to be a man you cannot dislike, of Mr. Kettle actually being one, of Laura refusing the easy comfort to make room for the truth, of Maeve putting crisps on his desk like a sacrament, of Katie making the town friendlier than it would have been without her, and he thinks that if you collect enough small domestic braveries they make a defence you can stand behind without having to memorise a speech.

In the morning the inevitable happens, not dramatically, not with sirens, but with an email and a sigh and then a phone call because everything has to have three forms now. The rugby club reports a loss of wire delivered to a back door that had been asking the universe to prove itself unkind, and the loss is discovered because a man who does balloons has a conscience about tickets. The shoe prints match the brand that smells like lunchtime fights and birthday money, and there is a picture from a cheerful yellow camera mounted above a back lane that shows a hood that reveals nothing and a gait that reveals a little too much. Owen puts it with the rest and resists the urge to draw a cartoon wolf on the map with a speech bubble saying “I did not bring a logo,” and instead he writes up the thing the way it wants to be written.

They go to see Two-Eights because this is the game and because there is a pleasure to be had in a conversation you know you will win by not needing anything immediate from it. He has a van that has undergone three different eras of care and none recently, and he has a face that looks as if he would practise being honest if there was an app. He denies everything and graciously allows that some things might have happened adjacent to him without his knowledge, and he says that wire is wire and a boy is a boy and who can be expected to understand the tides of either. Maeve does that thing she does where she speaks as if she has just woken from a restorative nap and tells him that the town has decided to learn his number, and he smiles the non-smile of a man who thinks the town can be made amnesiac on demand and will enjoy being wrong.

On his way back, Owen crosses the bridge and looks down at the river in its usual state of mind. A man is throwing a stick for a dog that is not named Nigel and the stick is not in competition with the river for the dog’s attention because the river is winning the game the dog is not playing, and the man laughs like a person who needed to hear his own noise. The town is already one foot into Monday, regulations and injustices and washing machines arguing back, and he lets the crowd fold him without thinking better of it. He has a centre that does not sulk in his pocket and it is ridiculous and helpful and he decides to be both about it. He thinks about stopping by the Quaker Meeting House to read the board that says there is something of God in everyone without wanting to fight the sentence, and then he thinks he will not, he will go to the shop that sells brass screws and ask unnecessary questions about countersinking because talking in that shop is a form of meditation for older men and he is trying on the idea.

By the time he reaches the station he has the shape of a small plan for his hands for tonight and the shape of a much less satisfying plan for his day, and he is greeted by the whiteboard which now features, under the green heading DOOR MEN, a new line in someone else’s hand that says FLOWERS?, which is both a joke and a decision waiting to be made. Griggs passes and reads it and pretends he doesn’t understand what the question is because if he acknowledges that nice things can be involved in ugly work he will have to stop storing his shirts in the freezer. “Yardley,” he says, “if you bring me good news I will pretend I deserve it.”

“I have news,” Owen says, and he holds out a watch that isn’t, and he holds back a centre that is, and he watches his boss be a man who requires a format. The day exists and he will go through it and he will find, later, that the part of it that stays is a ribbon he made behave, and he will be both annoyed and grateful, and he will tell no one and tell everyone by becoming someone’s quiet, manageable friend. He will text Maeve a photograph of a bowl of apples and ask if she wants to be sad about something on purpose, and she will answer with an emoji of a bin, and he will know that they are, despite the universe being what it is, going to make it to unimportant successes at least twice before Friday.Chapter Nine

By Tuesday the rain had decided it would be the sort that apologised while continuing, the sky writing sorry in a script you had to squint at to see. The station had the particular Tuesday smell of wet coats resigning themselves to radiators, and the whiteboard, which had acquired a life that occasionally bit, now featured FLOWERS? written in a more hopeful green than the person who wrote it would admit to owning. Griggs stood beneath the question like a man at a museum confronted by an installation he suspects is insulting him. He did a small sigh that could have been wind or could have been a comment on human nature and said, “If flower deliveries are now reconnaissance, I will require this town to find a new hobby.”

They were supposed to be writing the boring bits—doorstep warnings turned into numbers for the Home Office to argue over—but Marion Vale’s name was still sitting in the long corridor between case and file, and it made Owen’s pen drag when he wrote it. Laura had called early to say the funeral director had dates, as if dates were logical in an illogical week, and he had done the thing he does where he is helpful without committing his insides to the conversation. He had almost said, when she said they were thinking of flowers, that paper was an option. He had almost told her about a room above a shop where you could sit and make something that admitted it wasn’t going to last and decided to be beautiful anyway. He had not said it, because there are times when mixing your rooms is a species of theft.

Mr. Kettle solved the morning’s purpose by phoning to say Elsie’s door had been flirted with. His description: two men, both with the posture of men who have practised looking taller, one with new trainers that squeaked their own guilt, the other with a confidence that had to have been imported. They had leaflets that claimed the authority of lamination and a forged sense of neatness, and when he’d told them he would be calling their office to check, both had the flinch of men who do not enjoy being called offices. “And then,” he said, with the pleased dignity of a man who has crafted his own anecdote, “they posted a note through Elsie’s letterbox to say sorry they’d missed her and signed it, Love K. I have never been so furious at a letter of the alphabet.”

Owen held the note in a plastic sleeve twenty minutes later and tried not to recognise the shape of a joke he hated. The paper was cheap, the kind that thinks it is already a memory, the K done with a hand trying for friendliness and landing in sales. There was a tiny smear where the pen had been lifted too slow. It was not Katie’s left-handed wonk; it was someone who had watched kindness and attempted an impression. The ribbon that had been attached with a bit of tape had a very particular rib, and he saw Katie’s shelves as if they were a field map—the cheap satin, the expensive silk, the middle child she bought because people like options. This ribbon was the middle child, cream with a faint wire edge. The men had the sense to buy good material in small parcels. It made his throat feel thick with something he did not, strictly, have words for in this capacity. You cannot call ribbon evidence with the same face you use for blood.

Elsie, perched in her dressing gown like a small queen who had accidentally invited the village into her chamber, told the story of the knock as if it had been both a fright and a fable in the same minute. Her front room smelled of last night’s toast and old lavender. She showed them how Mr. Kettle had stood, exactly there, angled so he could see both men and still block them with a politeness they could not argue with without becoming too obvious. “They said the word vulnerable twice in the first minute,” she said, affronted. “People who use the word vulnerable at my gate often require me to teach them the meaning of the word no.”

“We’re collecting the rubbish they post,” Maeve said, with the smile she uses for women who have decided their house is sovereign territory. “Is the ribbon familiar?”

Elsie peered and sniffed it, because some women consider their noses to be an instrument of authority. “That is from the nice girl’s shop,” she said, as if identifying a cousin in a line-up. “The paper flowers. I bought one and it lasted five books. It did not make me think about watering. It made me think about being alive.” Then, because she had to reclaim some power from the morning, she added, “And I am not very cross. I am a bit cross. I am mostly tired of men with vans.”

On the way back, the rain remembered it had other towns and took itself off to annoy someone else. The air felt emptied out and newly available. They cut by the Meeting House because Ken had arranged himself into their week and because his flyers were suddenly part of the way certain men learned certain corners of the town. He was in the foyer with a woman who had the edges of grief pressed in so far it looked like neatness. He saw them and held up a finger in apology, then finished whatever word he was giving her—the kind of advice that can be moved from person to person without losing too much heat. When the woman had gone, he accepted the plastic sleeve like a man accepting a test. He looked at Love K and his mouth did the precise thing between insult and understanding.

“These bastards,” he said, very softly, in the way of a man who has once in his life deliberately chosen a swear word and is now very good at it. “They did this two years ago with my old logo. I wrote the words Talk to someone who cares on a leaflet and they stole the words and the font and used them to sell double glazing to widows. I changed everything. I got a lawyer who is six foot four in case that helps, and it didn’t.” He put the sleeve down with care, as if it might bruise. “You know this already, but I’ll say it anyway. Kindness is a currency and currencies get counterfeited. Take the ribbons, take the phrases, the colours, the bit of your day that assumes something soft is safe. They use the tone as a crowbar. It is why I do the rules now, even though they make me feel like a headmaster: trust your doubt, don’t make decisions at the door, ring a number you already know.”

“Do they come to your sessions,” Maeve asked. “The men who counterfeit kindness.”

“They come once,” Ken said, and smiled a little with his mouth and not his eyes. “They come to see whether the room can be turned into a shop. They don’t come back because the tea is free.”

They found themselves at Paper & Thread without saying they would go there, which was becoming a habit and therefore a risk. The bell did its small, self-conscious bird and Katie looked up with a what-now expression that softened when she saw it was them. She listened to the description of the note with her hands in ribbon, the way people stand better when holding something. She didn’t swear because she saved her swearing for glue and injustice, but her eyebrows did a curse. She fetched the middle-child ribbon and measured the rib between finger and thumb as if verifying a rumour. “Yes,” she said. “They bought four little rolls on Saturday—the day of the market. A man in a hat that had an argument with his head and a boy who took off and put back on his hood four times because he was rehearsing. They were charmers in the way that is born of a mother who is tired.”

“Hat,” Owen said. “Brown, felt. Beard like he’s keeping a snack safe under it.”

“That’s the one,” she said. “He bought and did not flirt, which should be a relief and made me angrier.” She reached under the counter and did a magician’s flourish with the cheerful yellow camera. “I listened to you and bought this. It likes to tell me it is uploading to a cloud, which sounds like a death. Do you want to look at my clouds.”

The pictures gave them the hat in a cloudy margin and the shape of a boy who could be six boys and the currency of cash. They had a time: eleven-forty-one. On the back of the receipt book Katie had written in pencil, because she writes her day down in little ways, ribbon x 4, wire medium x 2, cash, hat. She had also drawn a rectangle and shaded it because sometimes hands need a shape to sit in after they have dealt with a man who believed his politeness protected him.

Back at the station, the ribbon sat on the table like a polite animal that might bite. Griggs did his brief hover—he has at least three—and looked at the sleeve long enough to convey his displeasure at the universe’s insistence on being ironic. “Good,” he said, which meant be careful. “If I see Love G anywhere in this town I will retire. I will fold.” He left, carrying his weather with him. Maeve took her neat pen and added to the whiteboard under FLOWERS?: door decoy, ribbon from P&T, hat + hood, eleven forty-one, and then, because she can never resist making lists into something you can breathe inside, she wrote KINDNESS COUNTERFEIT in small letters above and then drew a line through it, not to cross it out but to hang things from it. Owen loved her for and despite that. He took a photograph of the board for his pocket and told himself he would delete it later because it looked like a poem and he didn’t trust poems in his phone.

At lunch he and Maeve were assigned to support Trading Standards on a street in Galmington that had decided to be watchful. TS were out in their tidy vests that meant something, talking about cold-calling zones like people introducing a diet to a room of pastries. Owen had refined his walk for these things: neither prowling nor strolling, an official amble. Two-Eights’ van was nowhere near because he was not stupid, but a cousin-cousin white transit with a winking indicator did a slow sweep and then kept on, which was as good as a wave. They spoke to three people on doorsteps who had had a knock and one who had had to close the door on an entire conversation he would once have felt obliged to finish. They met a woman who held her phone as if it were a weapon and took photographs of high-vis men without their permission “for the neighbourhood group,” which is a way of saying for her heart. A man in a fleece asked what the point of a no-cold-calling zone was when the cold was everywhere, and Owen, who is paid to answer those, said sometimes signs are like saints, sufficient to make a certain type of person rethink sin. The man in the fleece bought that and put it in his pocket for later.

The salvage yard presented itself to the afternoon like a thought you’d been trying to hold down. Owen went because either you go to the thing you are thinking about or it grows teeth while you attend to paperwork. Silas was in the back doing a practical man’s ballet with a length of copper that wanted to be unmanageable. Aiden was sweeping with a focus that suggested sweeping was either a meditation or a penance, and given his age perhaps both. When he saw Owen he straightened in the way boys straighten for approval even when they have decided they will not need it this week. Silas did not look up immediately, which meant he was practicing not giving Owen his entrance.

“You’re making your place very dishonest-looking,” Owen said, because the best way to turn a weather into a conversation is to punch it lightly in the arm. “Did your life coach tell you to rearrange the sign that says ‘we are legitimate’.”

“I told Ken I collect rude sentences for my private entertainment,” Rook said, finally taking a hand off the copper. “He said I might consider whether the entertainment was a symptom of loneliness. I told him to invoice my loneliness and we would see if it pays. He wrote it on his board, which made the loneliness feel seen and therefore smug.”

“We’ve got men using paper flowers to test houses,” Owen said. “Leaving notes that say Love K as if they have our sense of humour. They bought ribbon from Katie. Tell your boys if anyone uses the word Love in a font at a door I will personally teach them that affection can include court.”

Silas’s face did a flicker of something that had to work to get through. “I’ve seen one of those notes,” he said, as if confessing to finding poetry in a skip. “Left under a mat up by the old people’s bungalows. The boys you’re describing are hungry, and not for poetry. I told Two-Eights if I see his men pretending to be post, I will feed his van to a magnet. He laughed and sent me a message of a magnet with a sad face. It’s exhausting being charming when charm has gone out of fashion.” He thought for a beat, eyes going to the place in the yard where decades of municipal railings whispered to each other. “Also, for what it’s worth, one of that lot commissioned a frame,” he said. “I did not build it. I declined because the breath on the words smelled wrong. Asked about a trellis large enough to carry three men behind it. Asked about wheels he could bolt on and off. He thought he was being clever by not saying why. I thought I would consider breathing instead.”

“Frame,” Owen said. “For what.”

“For parties, he said,” Silas replied, and the word parties came from his mouth like a joke that had not learned its own punchline. “For wedding backdrops. For the bit where the bride can pretend to be a vine.”

“Wire from Paper & Thread went missing the same hour,” Owen said. “Rugby club ordered the week before. We have a hood in a cheerful yellow camera’s idea of a lane. If you see a rolling wall of flowers and men behind it, perhaps throw a chair through it.”

Rook hitched a shoulder. “We live in a town that can be talked into thinking it is smaller than it is,” he said. “A wall that rolls is a piece of theatre. Street theatre is a way to be a thief with applause. Tell your TS people to watch the back doors when the pretty thing goes by. And tell Ken that if he writes boundary again I will tattoo it on my forehead so he has to find a new word.”

He walked away before Owen could decide whether to forgive him for being useful. Aiden followed, then hesitated and came back with the awkward bravery of boys who have decided to do a kindness and wish the world would not make a fuss. He held out a bag from Paper & Thread. Inside was wire, medium, two. He said, “He sent me to pay Katie back,” and looked defiant and then immediately embarrassed that he had used the wrong face. “Not for the bad men. For something else he didn’t do. For buying time he didn’t spend. I don’t know. He’s rubbish at explanations.”

“He is,” Owen said. “He is recently rehearsing not being rubbish. It is very tiring to watch.”

That afternoon had the left-behind feeling the town sometimes gets when the children are at school and the day is clearing its throat for later. The rugby club sent over CCTV that did, beyond reasonable doubt, show a piece of moving scenery being wheeled past their back door—a trellis, improvised from builders’ mesh and the sort of pipe you buy when you are too nostalgic to commit to scaffolding. The flowers on it weren’t real but they weren’t embarrassing. Owen thought of the word glamour—glamour as a spell that changes the way a thing looks, glamour as the magic that makes you look and not see—and he said it out loud and Maeve nodded because she had been looking for that word all week. They watched the hood and the hat and a third man whose job seemed to be to frown in front of the wheels and make passersby feel impolite for interrupting a performance. Nobody could be expected to call the police on a backdrop.

“How did we arrive at villains with props,” Griggs said when shown, like a man confronted by an avant-garde production of a play he once liked in a village hall. “I am not funded for props.” Then, because even he can enjoy competence when it is happening in front of him, he put a finger on the hat in the printout and said, “Get him. If you can, get the grillman too.”

They did not get him that day because life is not a montage and because rolling walls are moves you make twice at most. They instead did the long small work—calls to clubs and halls and function rooms, to anyone who rented tables and joy by the hour, to ask if a frame had been ordered and if it had arrived with men who could charm a room into looking the other way. Trading Standards, cheeks flushed because being useful flips the blood to a new setting, began talking to neighbourhood groups about hospitality as tactic. Maeve did a radio spot, her voice trying not to sound like a school assembly, and told the town that love notes do not come through doors at tea time.

In the middle of that civics, a text arrived from Katie that said: a man is here buying ten peonies all in cream, says he can’t write with his hand because he broke it, could I tag each one Love K for him please, and I said no and he said I was unhelpful and I smiled like a saint. Also, he smells of a new van and old trouble.

Owen and Maeve did not run—there are times when you do not run to a shop because you do not want to bring your job’s heartbeat to a room where glue should be the loudest thing. They arrived briskly enough for the bell to do a flustered version of itself. Hat man was at the counter, hand in a sling that had not been tied by anyone trained in tying, speaking in a tone that had misused charm so long it had become sarcasm. He turned and saw their coats, and he did the brief, ridiculous calculation of whether he could hide ten cream peonies about his person, and then he did a smile that said he had decided to pretend he enjoyed being arrested.

“Gary,” Owen said, and that time the name landed like a stone. He took in the sling with the glance of a man counting exits and did not buy it, because the sling sat too high and had the wrong kind of knot, and because men like this rarely changed sides mid-week and broke themselves honestly. The shop’s ceiling seemed to lower itself as if to listen. He told hat man that he was wanted for a conversation because of a purse, because of a watch-shaped argument, because of a van and its numbers, because of a rolling trellis with a dishonest sense of theatre. The man tried to produce indignation like a trick and dropped it. Katie watched over the counter with the kind of attention that could flay or bless and decided on the second.

On the way out, before the door bell could perform, Ro and Min came in with the wind, Ro holding a bundle of wire like a champion holds a bouquet. He stopped dead at the sight of the sling and the hat and the constellations of adult faces that still hadn’t unclenched. He said, too loud, because children in rooms with cowboys either whisper or shout, “Is this the man who steals watches,” and the man said “I don’t,” and in that don't everything he did rearranged itself into the very shape of a yes.

Custody smelled like it always does, a mix of long day and recent mop. The paperwork was speeded by the fact that the hat man’s name had been collected three ways and would satisfy a judge. There was a moment, there is always a moment, when you see the thing inside the person you were concentrating on catching. He cradled his fake sling arm with a real tenderness that had not yet been used up by the morning, and he asked if he could keep the ribbon, and Owen, puzzled and irritated and human, put the small coil back into his pocket, because even men who counterfeit kindness sometimes need a bit of white silk to worry between their fingers while the afternoon tells them about themselves.

That evening the town allowed itself a little sunshine like a treat it had been promised on condition of good behaviour. Owen stood with his coat unbuttoned on the pavement outside Paper & Thread while Katie locked up, the key juddering because the world had taught it to fear being necessary. The butcher across the road was chalking prices and pretending to hate it. Ken passed and did his two-finger salute like a man in a film who had joined the army very late. Mr. Kettle emerged from a side street with two jonquils in a jar as if he had conjured them, and complimented the lock for surviving, and told Owen that Elsie had decided to write a fierce letter to the council and he had supplied adjectives by the bucket. They spoke, for three minutes, about nothing and everything, which is the only way to get through a Wednesday if you enforce laws in a town you also insist on liking.

Inside, the shop smelled like paper had decided to be a plant. Katie put the open till tray on the counter and counted with the seriousness of a person weighing something that wasn’t money. “They will be cross that you got hat man in my shop,” she said, and he braced for anger that did not come. “I am cross that they have learned the shape of a love note. I am cross that they are using my ribbon to teach fear to women who will die one day and do not need any more practice. I am possibly also cross that you made me like you and then brought your job into my room. It will pass. It has to.”

He nodded and did not say the careful thing he had prepared. He said instead, because his head had turned words over all afternoon until one unaddled itself, “I keep thinking about counterfeit. It would hurt less if it didn’t look so much like the thing. Real kindness leaves fingerprints that don’t show until later. Counterfeit kindness leaves a residue that is sticky on day one. We should teach that. That’s not very police.”

“We can do both,” she said. “You can teach law. I can teach ribbons. Ken can teach breathing and then I’ll bully him in the doorway about it. Mr. Kettle can give old ladies barley sugar and make them tell him their adult children aren’t telephoning enough. Rook can be wrong in public and right once a week for fun. You can catch the hat. I’ll sell cream. We’ll manage a town.”

They stood there, the two of them, in a small shop that sometimes performed theatre and sometimes saved the day’s balance with glue, and they agreed, without saying it, that the world would not be better if only it admitted the shape of criminal minds. It might be better if paper was allowed to be paper and hands were allowed to be hands.

He went home by the river because it would have been rude not to. The light had entered that late stage where it apologised to windows privately and made bridges into ideas. He made the centre that did not sulk because he had promised himself he would, and this one did not sulk in a way that felt like a tiny negotiated peace. He made a leaf that did not want to be in the same family as the other two and decided that sometimes families function regardless. He wrote down in his book not the arrests and the times and the names, though those went somewhere too, but a sentence he would not have owned last year: do not let the counterfeit teach you to distrust the real. He thought it might be a thing he could live in for a week.

Just before sleep could trick him, his phone made the noise that meant someone who wasn’t quite allowed was asking to be allowed anyway. It was Laura. She had been through her mother’s drawers again, she said. She had found an old jeweller’s box with the impression of a watch long gone on velvet. Beneath the velvet, in the space where a spare link had once lived, there was a scrap of paper folded so small it had thought it was dust. On it, in a script that had remembered how to be young, was written K—Pls fetch hedgehog from Wendy’s, x. It was nothing, she said, and also faced the right way. Owen, who had spent a day watching notes make rooms bigger and smaller, said, “Keep it,” and then added, because it was the thing he had, “and bring it to the funeral so we can put it in the bowl with the apples.” She did not ask him why apples, and he did not tell her about October, and the language they didn’t have found them a room and let them sit down.

By dawn the town is a map of damp streets and sleep-warmed windows, an uncertain sketch washed with grey. The tower of St Mary Magdalene leans into the light as if bending to listen to the traffic. The early bus coughs along East Street, the river makes a noise like a held breath. In the police station, they keep the night in a tray and pour it out only when they absolutely must.

He stands at the window above the car park and watches condensation bloom on the windscreen of an unmarked Vauxhall. The glass fogs over as though the car might be shy. Detective Sergeant Owen Yardley presses a knuckle into his right eye and makes a little firework of colour on his eyelid. Behind him, fluorescent lights hum their cheap unending sermon.

“You’re still here?” Maeve Kerslake asks, appearing with two mugs. She sets one down, tea pale as weak sunlight. The corner of her mouth has a habitual smudge of sarcasm, as if life keeps touching her there.

“More or less,” he says. “The Vauxhall is definitely here. It’s trying to grow moss.”

“Take the new Mondeo,” she says. “Pretend you’re important.”

“I’m not important,” he says, and takes the tea.

“You did a twelve to twelve. You’re permitted to talk about yourself like someone people should listen to.” Her hair is in a plait that has escaped several times and been wrangled back with office supplies. A paperclip shows in the twist.

He nods at the whiteboard. A dead man from Halcon estate with a bruise like a moon under his eye. A burglary that turned into something else mid-sentence, as some sentences do when you say them out loud.

“Credit cards didn’t go,” Owen says. “Just the tin with coins for the meter.”

“Maybe they needed change. Everyone always needs change in this town.” Maeve sips. “Do you dream of crime when you do these shifts?”

“I dream of the vending machine turning against me. The flap refuses to open. I can see the crisps, but they’re for other people.”

“You’re not wrong. Last week it only took ten pences. I thought I’d entered a 1986 wormhole.”

They stand a while, each doing the separate work of not thinking about what happens next; the paperwork, the callouts, the small acts of tidiness that might avert a catastrophe or might just be tidy for the sake of it. On the sill there are three dead flies and someone’s spare ID lanyard coiled like a sea snake.

At nine, they go to High Street where a man in a gilet has been standing very still for long enough to make everyone nervous. He is staring at the window of a craft shop called Paper & Thread. The display is a riot of lime and violet and coral flowers, so thin the light can pass through them and still be colourful. Petals like moth wings, like pastry. A butcher from across the way has come out to smoke and sneer.

“Go on then,” the butcher says to the gilet man, “you gonna propose to the window?”

The man doesn’t answer. He has stopped crying. He looks like someone who has just agreed with himself not to do something. Owen speaks to him softly and asks him his name and whether anything is going on that would be made better by a walk to Vivary Park and a talk on a damp bench. The man nods and nods again and they do that.

While Maeve handles the butcher’s need to be entertained and the shopkeeper’s very genuine fright at having a crying man press his forehead to her tulips and roses (paper roses, not roses roses, obviously), Owen is left for twenty seconds in front of the glass. The flowers are fastened to a trellis of painted twigs, spirals of green tissue suggesting vines. Somebody has taken time. Somebody’s hand was here, then there, then pinched a fold and breathed out and glued and placed. A little card announces a Saturday workshop. Paper peonies for Mother’s Day, it says. No experience necessary. Tea and biscuits provided. Katie. The script is looped and soft.

His mother used to roll pastry like a prayer she once knew by heart and could remember with her hands if not her mouth. When she died it was October and his sister put a bowl of apples on the table and nobody touched them. After the funeral, the house smelled like rain in coats. They were not the kind of family that kept flowers.

“What are you doing?” Maeve asks from behind him, after the man in the gilet has walked away with the leaf-shadow of a decision on his face.

“Looking,” he says.

“At the window.”

“Mm.”

“You thinking of moonlighting? Sergeant Owen Yardley, florist.”

“They’d be paper,” he says.

“Those are paper?”

“Looks like it.”

She laughs. “It looks like my nan’s sitting room threw up.”

On the way back to the station, the Mondeo makes a little rattle like a cough pretending it’s not a cough. Owen drives deliberately, as if the white lines are made of china.
