He has always done things with his hands that way. When he writes he presses hard and nearly breaks the pen. When he touches a shoulder he does it as if the person might bruise. His hands do not always believe that they belong to him.

They stop at the crossing by the County Ground. Rain is trying and then not trying, the way it does in Somerset, like someone learning to juggle. Above the stand, gulls shout their thoughts on eternity. The light goes green. Maeve says something that makes him want to be somewhere else for a moment.

“Silas Rook was in the paper,” she says. “You see?”

“No,” he says, but the shape of the name finds all the little grooves in his mind that it has worn over the years. Silas Rook, the town’s cleverest ghost. Owner of a salvage yard called Rook & Rooke, a shop for broken brass and pitted iron and chairs missing crucial legs, a dealer in secondhand glories. Also, historically, well-connected to people who take what isn't theirs and sell it to people who pretend they didn’t know.

“Photo from some charity bash,” Maeve says. “He’s wearing a tie as if he understands a tie.”

“What charity?”

“Dogs with insomnia.” She shrugs. “Something with Labrador in the name. His date has hair like she’s been electrocuted pleasantly.”

He doesn’t say anything. It scratches at him, Silas Rook in print. As if Rook is a real man. Tall with a shaved head, a scar through the eyebrow like someone drew a line to make sure he could be recognized at a distance. A voice that distracts you from the words it is saying. The first time Owen arrested him they were both younger and Rook smiled in the back of the police van as if he were the one driving.

At the station door, DCI Griggs is hovering like a cloud that is about to be weather. He is the kind of man who looks like he keeps his shirts in the freezer. “Yardley,” he says. “You look like you’ve met an idea and you’re not sure if you like it.”

“I met a window,” Owen says.

“I don’t think this is the time for windows,” Griggs says, not smiling. He never smiles. If he does it will be by accident and in private. “We’ve got a meet at ten. Bring legible notes from Halcon. If you can do legible.”

“I can do legible.”

“Good. Kerslake, I need you in court with me after. The Blagdon appeal. Wear something that suggests you don’t own a dog.”

In the briefing room someone has left a magazine open on the table with an article titled The Gentle Power of Craft. There are photos of small birds made of felt, buttons with faces, a woman cupping a teacup as if it is a planet she is responsible for. He almost puts the magazine in the bin. He doesn’t. He slides it under the chair just as if the room might be offended.

While Griggs reads out things the room already knows and adds the small changes that transform knowing into chastened understanding, Owen finds a piece of torn paper in his pocket with the words Paper peonies for Mother’s Day and a phone number in looped handwriting. He cannot remember putting it there. He must have. Or the window put it there.

“Yardley,” Griggs says, “are we with you?”

“Always,” Owen says automatically, catching up with the way sentences are being assembled around him. Responsibilities. Other people’s days. It all fits like furniture when you get it right, and bruises your shin when you don’t.

He phones the number on his lunch hour, because there is a stupid little buzz in the back of his skull that won’t stop. The phone rings three times and then a voice says, “Hello, you’ve reached Katie, I might be covered in glue. Leave a message and I’ll ring you back if my hands aren’t stuck together.”

He hangs up. Then feels ridiculous and phones again, and this time the voice is real-time. “Hello?” Katie says. “Is this glue? Who is this?”

“I found your number,” he says, and hears how that sounds. “In the window. Not the number, the card. I’m not, that sounds like I’m a weirdo.”

“Weirdos welcome,” she says. “It’s Saturday three till five. You bring your hands and I bring the tissue paper and nobody dies.”

He almost says we can’t guarantee that. He says “Thanks” instead and writes down the address. It’s the back room above Paper & Thread. A narrow stair that will smell of cotton and dust.

When he doesn’t show in the break room after lunch Maeve wanders down the corridor to find him and he is in the evidence store looking at a plastic bag with a small ragged thing inside. It is the left-over of a party hat, the crown part, crushed. It smells faintly of hair spray. He is looking at it the way you might look at a creature that doesn’t know you’re watching, as if it could spook and run.

“What,” Maeve says.

“Thought it was something else,” he says. “Nothing. Leave it.”

“What did you think it was.”

“A flower.”

“That looks like something you find under a table when everyone’s gone home.”

“I know.”

She loves him. Maeve loves him like a sibling you didn’t choose but are relieved to find you like. She loves him enough to say, “Come to the pub tonight and let someone else pick the music.”

“I might have somewhere to be.”

“Oh really. Hot date with a photocopier.”

“A class,” he says, and then he is annoyed because he didn’t mean to say it like that, like a secret. He looks at the bag again, the crushed fake crown. He doesn’t want his shame touching that pity. “A craft thing.”

Her face does something particular. “Because of the window,” she says.

“Because of hands,” he says, surprising himself. “Because I’d like to use them for things that are not this.”

She nods slowly. “You want me to come and be the loud one in the corner so you can pretend you’re there by accident.”

“No,” he says. “Thanks. I want to go and be the quiet one in the corner because I can be.”

“You never are.”

“I know.”

“I’ll send you photos of crisps in honour of your absence.”

The occurrence comes at three—in the small cul-de-sac behind a shuttered off-license where all the bins have been overturned as if some enormous animal passed through and was affronted by the smell. The lad in the tracksuit is sixteen and has blood on his knuckles, not quite his own. There are five boys and the shape of a fight that could have been much worse. Owen stands between and not between, a positioning that is second nature now, and speaks in a tone he sometimes recognises as being not his but borrowed from an old PE teacher who smoothed everything with a joke until somebody cried.

One of the boys wears a paper crown from Christmas. It is March, but his face is a winter that never finished. The crown sits at a chaotic angle and splits when he lurches. It spills down past his ear like some indecisive petal. Normally, Owen would miss it. Normally he wouldn’t, but he would not name it. This time his eyes catch and keep it and it feels like a sign in a language he is just starting to learn.

“Enough,” he says, and the boys are relieved. Relief is the unmentioned agreement at these moments. Everyone wanted out. No one wanted to be the one who said so.

They take statements and call two sets of parents who arrive so full of breath and opinions that the small yard is brimming. Words are said about school and about what certain boys are and are not like. Someone says “feral” with a satisfaction he does not like at all. In the quiet after, all the boys gone, the bins upright again, the air smelling faintly of stale beer and wet cardboard and a little of fear, he pulls the paper crown from the gutter. He does not bag it. He folds it into a square. He puts it in his pocket.

By five, the light is falling over the rooftops like a shirt shrugged off and left on the back of a chair. He stands in front of the narrow staircase to the room above Paper & Thread and thinks about not going in. The thought is a small, neat square in his chest. He could take it out and unfold it and read it: stay away, people might look. People always look. But people always look. And then they look somewhere else.

He climbs and his foot hits the edge of a step that is not as deep as all the others and he thinks, in that superstitious way you think when something is almost not touched at all: if the step had been full size, I might not have noticed it, and I might be someone else. The door at the top opens before he can knock. Katie has hair in a knot and long, gluey fingers. Her jumper is the colour of a pond in May.

“You’re the window man,” she says.

He is too tired to be embarrassed. “I might be.”

“Well, if you’re somebody else, you’re still welcome.” She stands aside. “We’ve got tea and a plate of biscuits that are pretending not to be stale.”

There are five other people in the room. Two women of retirement age who look like cousins and have brought identical bags with seaside scenes on them. A boy of about eleven who is accompanied by an aunt or an older sister, who has a kind face with firm edges. And a man with a beard who looks like he is here under the cover of supporting somebody else who did not, in the end, come.

“We’re doing peonies,” Katie says, “because peonies are basically glamour crumpled up. We’ll start with templates so no one panics. Panic is available if required, but best done quietly.”

They sit. He sits. He is like a very tall book leaning itself casually at the end of a shelf, his knees not sure where to go. Katie layers tissue in her hands—pale cream, a pink that makes him think of the inside of a seashell, a darker crimson, a ridiculous ultraviolet that he chooses immediately because somebody has to. The paper is thin as breath but not fragile. It is strong in the way webs are.

“Right,” Katie says. “This is the trick. It’s not really a trick. Twist the middle like a tiny sweet. Then pinch. Then you make a crease and the crease is your friend even if it looks like a mistake.”

He has never thought of a crease as a friend. In evidence bags, in shirts hung from door handles, in old photographs with the line across the boy’s smile where someone once folded the memory in half and put it in the back of a drawer—lines have been borders, endings. He pinches the tissue. He twists. It feels like he’s wringing out a thought.

“Exactly,” Katie says, looking at his hands with the kind of patience that makes him want to be teachable. “People think flowers are symmetrical and perfect. They’re not. They’re extravagant and wrong. That’s why they’re interesting.”

The woman who came with the boy says, “I always thought peonies were just roses if they’d had too much gin,” and the boy snorts and the man with the beard lets out a sound that might be the beginning of a laugh before he remembers himself.

“I’m Owen,” he says, because not saying your name in a small room feels like wearing a mask at a children’s party.

“Katie,” she says again. “And that’s Mrs. Glass and that’s Mrs. Also-Glass, and that’s Ro and his aunt Min, and that’s Greg who will probably tell you about boats if you ask him anything at all.”

“I can do boats,” Greg says. “I can do rudders and things for keeping water out.”

The paper rustles like snow that would rather be rain. He folds and pinches and breathes in glue and the soft wild smell of the dyes. His first attempt looks like the aftermath of a cake fight. His second looks like something a bird might sit on if desperate. His third is a peony only in that it is not a table or a chair. Katie takes it, fluffing with her fingers like a barber waking up a haircut. “There you are,” she says. “You let it be messy. It does the rest.”

He puts his flowers on the table and a hush happens in him. It is not dramatic. It is a small room made in a larger room. He has made something that is not evidence or advice or a report or a chase. It is barely a thing and yet his hands say: yes.

“Who are you when you’re not folding paper?” Min asks him, carefully not making it sound like a question that can end a day.

He swallows. He has practiced the joke you practice when you have this job. “I’m the kind of person who walks round with heavy keys and makes people’s kitchens look smaller. I’m a policeman.”

The boy, Ro, says “Do you have a gun?”

“No,” he says. “Just a sarcasm launcher. It’s tethered.”

“Is that dangerous?”

“Mostly to the operator.”

Mrs. Also-Glass says, “My Trevor was a policeman. He did the phone calls to tell people things.” She looks down at her flower and says, “He was good at that and not good at coming home.”

Katie looks at him and then doesn’t, which is a kindness he appreciates utterly. They work until the plate is only sugar and crumbs and all the tea has become brown with the dust of being left to think too long. Ro makes a peony that is almost a dahlia and calls it a hero flower because it didn’t mind being wrong. Owen makes five, because the movements have become, if not graceful, at least something he can trust his muscles to remember for longer than the moment.

The man with the beard, Greg, says, “I drive to Minehead sometimes. To look at the edge. You can see the water thinking.”

Min says, “It doesn’t think, love.”

“It thinks more than I do,” he says.

Walking back down the narrow steps, Owen has the carefulness of a person carrying eggs up a hill. In a box is the flower he will never give to his mother. He knows it sounds like a stage direction from a play you would roll your eyes at. He knows what it is, and he does not mind.

On the pavement, the air has become a compromise between rain and not rain. The butcher across the way is closing up, a string of sausages on a hook in the window like a necklace someone gave him as a joke. The butcher sees the box and says, “What you got there then, Sarge? Valentines in March? Bit sad.”

Owen smiles a little. “It’s paper,” he says.

“Paper,” the butcher repeats, and adds, “What’s next? Straw. Is this a farm.”

He moves on. Behind him the shop door clicks. At the corner by the bus stop a boy with a shaved head and shoes too white to have been worn in the rain says, “You Yardley?” and there is a flinch in the name.

“Sometimes,” Owen says.

“Silas sent me,” the boy says. He looks left and right even though that is, in itself, the shout of something being not quite on the level. “Wants you to know he doesn’t have your watch. I don’t know what that means. He laughed when he said it. He says you’ll understand.”

It is an old joke, a job from last year involving a box of spoons and a brave dog and a gullible burglar. Silas had palmed the watch from his wrist as if they were playing cards. Later, as if they were lovers. He had returned it with a handshake that felt like the chin of a statue. He always wanted to make a stage of things; to make a room into a story and put himself at the center of it. He is the kind of man who has learned both his best angles and his worst.

“What’s your name?” Owen asks.

“Why.”

“Because someone gave you one.”

The boy thinks about it and remembers his mother for long enough to say, “Aiden.”

“Okay, Aiden. Tell him I understood. Tell him to stop sending children to see me.”

“He says you could do with someone to run for your lunch if you’re so bothered by children.”

Owen smiles again. “You know what a life is? Not having someone else run for your lunch,” he says, and it feels like he’s talking to himself, to the younger one, to a version who would have liked that job because it is performing loyalty without having to mean it. He gives the boy a fiver. “This is not payment,” he says. “It’s for not standing in the road. Food goes a long way.”

Aiden looks at the note as if it might bite him and then puts it so carefully into his pocket that it is, for a moment, moving. He nods and goes. In the reflection of the bus shelter glass, Owen sees himself holding the box of peonies and thinks, Christ. If this were a film I’d be unbearable.

At home, the flat is the kind that estate agents call bright and a little quirky. It has a window that looks over the river and into someone else’s window where a woman waters a plant that might be plastic. He puts the peony box on the table and stands making small adjustments to the petals that no one else will ever notice. He could not stop his mother dying. He could not fix his sister’s dry, very private grief. He could not undo the way the job takes a little bite from his sense of humour every day. But he can make this. It is not a victory. It is not even a battle. It is a small thing in a room that otherwise holds practical things with plugs.

His phone vibrates with a text. It’s Maeve. Did you do your paper oath, she writes. Are you now a priest.

He writes back, I am now Chief Superintendent of Tissue. Bow down.

She sends three skull emojis and a photo of a packet of salt and vinegar with the caption: your loss is noted.

At two in the morning he wakes and the flat is all water noises. Somewhere a pipe taps its own skin to stay awake. He goes to the kitchen for water and is frightened by his own reflection, a flash of someone else’s tired nemesis in the black glass. He has that dream again, the one where he has to write a sentence that matters with a pen whose ink keeps becoming water, then smoke, then paper itself. He wakes with his hand curled as if pinching something invisible.

The next day, a body that might be a murder and might be a poorly-timed heart problem sits in the centre of an upstairs room in a house on Greenway Avenue. The Queen Anne chair looks offended to be near death. The woman's hands are neatly folded on her chest, which no one did. Or maybe someone did. There is a paper flower on the mantle. A peony.

“Everyone has peonies,” Maeve says, shaking her head. “It’s a trend like planks on walls. Like having a sign that says kitchen as if you were going to cook in the lounge by mistake.”

“This is tissue,” he says, and he hates that his voice is the voice of a man who has new knowledge and would like everyone else to sit up straight to hear it. “This is…there’s a wire inside. See.”

Maeve looks at him and smiles like a fox pretending to be a dog. “You are allowed to know things,” she says. Then, quieter, “What do you think?”

He thinks of Katie’s hands and her simple instructions and the way the paper answered to being touched like it was always going to be like that. He thinks of the window, of the crying man, of Aiden with his too-white shoes and the butcher leaning with his untidy contempt. He thinks of Silas Rook’s boy in the bus shelter and what it means to have messengers in a small town that has only so many metres of pavement. He thinks of the stain on the dead woman’s blouse that is tea and reached there because of a hand that shook or didn’t shake. He thinks of all of it.

“I think,” he says, “there’s a group in town making peonies.” It is ridiculous. It is possibly obvious. He says it anyway. “And I think I need to go and ask questions and not frighten people. And I think we should not tell Griggs yet because he will make his mouth do that thing.”

Maeve nods. “The mouthing. It is very tabletop.”

He lifts the tissue paper flower with his gloved hand and studies the ribbon that binds it. There is a tiny tag. He reads aloud. “Love K.”

“There’s going to be a store with a register,” Maeve says.

“There is.”

“Of course there is.”

Back at Paper & Thread, the bell above the door tries to ring in a demure manner and fails like a bullfinch wedged into a teaspoon. Katie looks up and does not look surprised. “Who died?” she asks.

“Please don’t ask that,” he says, and exhales. Then, “A woman. She had one of yours.”

“Oh God,” Katie says. Her hands flutter. “Which one.”

“Peony. Cream.”

“I make a lot of those,” she says, and then, because she knows what it sounds like, she adds, “That’s not me being… Oh you know.”

“I know.” He shows her the tag. “You write your initials on them?”

“Only for the classes where we box them up. Usually I put the customer’s name because it makes people feel they’re not just buying something probably made by a robot. That one was… last Thursday? I remember because I burned my fingertip with the glue gun and I had to do it with my left hand. So the K is wonky.”

He looks. The K is a little drunk. The fact pleases him inordinately. It is not an AI-perfect K. It is a person letter. “Do you keep sales records?”

“For classes,” she says. “Yes. Not for individual bouquets because we’re still on a cash bell-jar system since Izzy messed up the PayPal. Why. Is this—Oh God.”

“It’s probably nothing to do with the flower,” he says. “It’s a window.”

“The man in the window? He came back, you know. He bought a little bunch of bluebells for his daughter. She was wearing Spider-Man pajamas under her coat.”

“I’m glad you say it like that,” Owen says, “as if things sometimes go right from offscreen.”

Katie smiles with only half of her mouth. “They do. And sometimes the wrong things also do that. You look tired. You need sleep and a ridiculous breakfast.”

“Later.” He doesn’t say there is never a later. He looks around at the shelves stacked with tissue like folded air and ribbon spools like little hard suns. It is a room made of patience. He leaves her with his card but not with the weight of his day, because that is his to carry and to put down in the correct rooms reserved for that purpose.

At his desk, Griggs is waiting with a pencil held in a way that suggests he is about to stab a piece of paper into obedience. “Yardley,” he says. “You know what I like? I like officers who do their job and don’t form passionate attachments to crafts.”

“I’m very attached to the stapler,” Owen says.

“Don’t,” Griggs says. “Rook has been seen near Priorswood with two of his choirboys and a van that may or may not belong to his cousin’s cousin. We’re told,” and he makes quotation marks you can see in his voice even if his fingers don’t do them, “we’re told he’s got a line on some very charming copper piping. Do copper pipes charm you, Yardley?”

“I dream of them,” Owen says.

“Good. Take Pond and get yourself charmed.” Griggs looks at his hands and sighs. “And for Christ’s sake lose the paper on your sleeve. It looks like your laundry attacked you.”

Owen looks down. There is a tiny confetti of cream on his cuff, like he has been blessed by a very specific and benevolent weather. He brushes it off, then flicks his fingers in a silly little shake, as if to get rid of water. When he looks up, Maeve is watching him with a quiet expression that is too kind to hold eye contact with. He looks away first.

At Priorswood, the van is a van and the pipes are pipes and Silas Rook is not there. He is always not there precisely when you have made a plan to include him. He is a weather system. They do the necessary paperwork and let the paramedics tend to the man who cut his hand on a sharp end of pipe and tried to pretend his hand was not bleeding until he left a trail that made it impossible to pretend anything. There is a child watching from the upstairs window across the street, a curtain held back with exactly as much strength as can be applied without it becoming obvious.

Later, at three, Owen sees Rook in the town centre as if Rook knew that three would be a time when Owen would be doing his thinking walk. He is outside the Castle Hotel, leaning on the wall like he was born to. He has a cup of coffee and a grin that looks like it has been ironed.

“Yardley,” he says, delighting in the syllables like a man who has won a raffle and is waiting for you to notice. “You look like someone’s favourite schoolteacher. What’s that about.”

“Go home,” Owen says, but his mouth says it like a joke. He thinks of the boy Aiden and the message and the watch and the way Rook never stands in the middle of a pavement. Always the edge, always the new angle. “There’s a way of being, Silas, where you don’t involve other people’s children.”

“Now, that’s an interesting philosophical claim,” Rook says. “You live in a world where other people’s children are like rain. They just happen to you. You should pick a different world if you don’t like it.”

“You sent a boy with a message. Don’t do it again.”

“I employed a now very slightly richer courier,” Rook says. “He said you gave him a fiver. Are you trying to outbid me? I’d start a bit higher if I were you.”

“I’m not playing with you,” Owen says, then ruins it by smiling.

“You always are,” Rook says, and drinks his coffee. “We’ve been playing for years, and you know what I found out last week? It’s not even tennis. It’s pelmanism. We turn over the same two cards and pretend to be surprised that they match.”

“What happened last week,” Owen says, because Rook never says things he doesn’t want you to pull.

“I joined a thing,” he says. “But I think I’ll let you find out by reading the paper like you pretended not to.”

“You joined… a gym,” Owen says, and Rook wriggles with pleasure.

“I joined a gym for my brain. Because my brain was lonely and keeps doing old routines. I thought, Silas, maybe don’t. Maybe learn a new one. Maybe stop doing the thing where you put your hand in someone else’s pocket and take something that doesn’t belong to you.”

Owen feels a laugh rise and refuses it. “You joined a cult.”

“I hired a life coach,” Rook says, calmly, and watches his face closely. “Do you like it. Does it look good on me.”

He thinks of the craft magazine and the peonies and the dead woman and all the boys in all the cul-de-sacs waiting for someone to choose a sentence for them. He thinks of Silas Rook with a life coach and what that would look like. The coach would have to be a person not afraid of the part of a man who does not want to be touched. The coach would have to have paper hands, strong as webs. It is absurd in the way that suggests it might, for ten minutes in a rare hour, be true.

“This town,” Owen says, in the tone of blessing you give to a relative who is wearing a swimming hat at Christmas, “this town.”

Rook looks at him, and for a second there is a light he doesn’t show anyone else. It says I am a person with a past, and I might want something different than the thing I have learned to want. It says a lot for a second. Then his mouth goes back into its proper place and he taps the cup with his teeth. “I’ll send my man your watch,” he says, smirking. “We can all be honest. I never had it.”

“You did,” Owen says.

“I did,” Rook says, and strolls away, getting the last line as always, even when he admits to the mistake.

In the station, someone has written on the whiteboard in a fat green marker: who moved the stapler. Below it someone has written: grief. Then someone else: life coach.

He puts the peony on his desk. It looks ridiculous. Maeve looks at it and says, “I had a teacher once who used to pin silk flowers to her cardigans because she liked looking like a sofa.”

“What do I look like,” he asks.

“Like a man with a flower on his desk.”

“That will do.”

He sits. The paperwork rustles. The phone rings. Somewhere a door closes too hard because that is how the person feels and the door is the only thing that won’t mind. He writes the dead woman’s name. He writes to Katie to ask if the tag jogs a memory. He writes Rook in the margin and underlines it and does not have a theory he can call elegant.

At five, when the light outside is the colour of tea with milk left in the cup, Griggs stands by his chair and looks at the flower as if it has made a remark. “We are not a party,” he says.

“Understood,” Owen says, without moving.

“Don’t let your… hobbies… bleed,” Griggs says. “You let anything bleed enough it becomes the whole room. I don’t want to stand in a room and find myself drowning in someone’s embroidery.”

“It’s paper,” Owen says.

“Everything is paper,” Griggs says. “Until it burns.”

After, he goes to the river and leans on the railing like a cliche that has forgiven itself. A little group of teenagers share a bag of chips and talk about a teacher’s boots as if they are a political scandal. A boy throws a stone and misses the water and looks around to see if the stone itself is going to laugh. The peony sits in a ridiculous and beloved fashion in his pocket, warm from his hand. He tries to imagine Rook sitting in a circle talking about values with a person in a sweater. He tries to imagine it with kindness. He fails, but not entirely. A gull shouts and the sky answers with a shift of grey that could be a promise or could be nothing at all.

If he is honest—and he is not always—he likes the feeling of the paper against his palm. He likes the way something thin as breath can be encouraged into a shape you can name. It is not control. It is not rescue. It’s softer. He doesn’t have a word for it yet. He tells himself language will catch up. It has to. It always does, eventually. It always does, until it doesn’t.

And in a house on Greenway Avenue a ribbon hangs from a mantle, missing its weight. And in a salvage yard called Rook & Rooke a man with a scar through his eyebrow looks at his own hands and thinks: these could be used for something that is not making doors open. And in a small room above a shop that smells of tissue and glue, a woman writes down names on a list and underlines one because she knows that people who bring their shoulders down off their ears for an hour might need a reason to come again. And in the station on Shuttern the night collects itself in the pigeonholes, as it always does, ready for the shift to change, and the town leans into the next thing the way a cyclist leans into a curve, hoping for balance, almost finding it, sometimes falling anyway.

By morning the light over Greenway Avenue has the overstated politeness of a guest who has arrived too early and is trying not to rustle. The house holds still as if taught to, the kind of semi-detached that looks like it was built to accept sensible conversations and wipeable grief. They do the door again because they always do the door again, the ritual of the threshold a way of admitting there was a before and now there is an after. The hallway smells faintly of lavender polish and the breath of carpets that have known slippers. On the console table is a bowl with a handful of coins and a postcard from Weston-super-Mare showing the pier in a light so artificial it has failed into romance. The Queen Anne chair in the front room remains affronted in the way certain furniture becomes when the human story decides to do something inconvenient on its watch. The woman is still, more very asleep than anything else, except for the tiny wrongs—colour, temperature, the way the spine negotiates gravity when it is done pretending to be a string attached to a kite. The peony from the mantel is in a bag now with a little card stapled and numbers that turn the word flower into a line of a report. The ribbon that once held it is hanging like a small fete that didn’t come off.

The pathologist does the small, tender work that makes television lie. He does not announce a time of death like a man opening a parcel to a room of people waiting to be pleased. He looks at wrists and nails and the inside of the lips where bruises begin talking before they are noticed. He speaks in little fractions because the body at this point is a fraction of what it was. “Natural,” he says, and then corrects himself because precision is a form of love. “Probably natural. Underlying. But there’s a bruise here that wants a story. Maybe a fall. Maybe a wrist held. Maybe nothing.” He looks at the left wrist and the pale blank where a watch lived its life for a long time and now is elsewhere. He doesn’t write burglary. He doesn’t write theft. He writes absence and leaves it for other rooms with other people to decide what absence means.

Maeve does her dance through the rooms, her notebook a net that catches the fish that want to be caught and several minnows that will be let go later because scale matters. “Milk in the fridge,” she says in the tone she reserves for evidence hiding in plain sight. “Half a pint. Sell-by two days ago. Tea stains on two mugs. Both with lipstick—one a mauve that wants to be brown and one defiant carnival pink. She didn’t have guests in mauve lipstick. Or did she repaint her mouth between mugs.” The bedside table holds two blister packs that have surrendered one pill each but at different hours. A knitted shawl hangs on the end of the bed like a note in a soft language. In the kitchen the radio is on at a whisper, some presenter being too cheerful for a morning that hadn’t been asked to accommodate any cheer at all. On the fridge door there is a magnet with the phone number of a taxi firm and a babysitter’s flyer with perforated tabs; none of the tabs have been taken, which has always felt like a quiet little sadness to Owen, as if the babysitter has been waiting in a room for years, her hair done for nothing.

House-to-house is a choreography with tea. A neighbour in a lilac fleece does that thing where she begins a sentence with “Funny thing, actually,” and the funny thing is interesting but not independently capable of carrying us to a conclusion. She saw a man about a week ago who might have been a son or might have been the Internet; he brought in shopping with the way of somebody embarrassed to be holding bags. Another neighbour who has barbeque utensils in a bucket by the back door offers the idea that a white van without signage is, all white vans are, practically a confession. It isn’t helpful and he will gladly repeat it to the tape recorder if asked. A woman two doors down says the dead woman used to be a teaching assistant and then became not that when her knees failed to be excited by flight of stairs, and she spent a great deal of time writing to the council about hedges becoming more than hedges. As with all people who are newly dead, the town is gently editing her into a story that sounds as if everyone involved had a plan.

Family arrive in pieces because that is how families work, one person already halfway through the day’s argument, another ready to be reasonable, one with their phone as a shield and one with naked hands. The daughter, whose name is Laura and who has a council lanyard in her pocket that she touches without putting on, stands in the hallway and swallows back a year’s worth of unmade calls. She is wearing a jacket that is supposed to look smart and a pair of boots that knew a much younger December. She looks at Owen as if he is an electrician who has come to mend a socket and she is embarrassed that her whole house is on fire. “She was fine,” Laura says, and the word fine looks as if she has made it out of aluminium foil, pressed neat, and it is crumpling in her hands already. She names the second mug’s lipstick. “That will have been Wendy. Thursdays. Wendy brings pink. Mum hates pink and drinks it anyway out of politeness.” The watch gets its own little scene. “Mum’s watch,” Laura says, before the question reaches the room. “She never took it off, even in the bath. She said time was the thing that got away the fastest and she wanted to hold something that had it in.” When asked if anyone would take it she blinks, offended by the verb but bound to consider it. “No. I mean—who would. Maybe she put it down. Maybe she—I don’t know. Maybe nothing.”

The tag in the bag with the peony is reproduced in Owen’s head when he closes his eyes. Love K, written by a left hand pretending confidence. A list of names at Paper & Thread will be ordinary in the way that lists are. It will have Karens and Kates and a Kelly who spells it with a single l because her mother thought that looked continental. He thinks of the way Katie had said “I burned my finger,” and how the small change in pressure on a pen turned a letter into a different animal. He thinks he might be constructing a puppetry of coincidence because it pleases him to imagine that the world is made of handholds.

At the shop, mid-morning, tissue paper is a weather, squares being lifted and lowered like very obedient flags. The bell on the door produces its strangled finch noise and Katie looks up the way a person looks up when they know a person will be there and they have already prepared their face to receive them. He shows her a photograph of the tag taken on his phone through plastic. “Left hand K,” she says immediately, in the tone of a person pointing at themselves caught in their own CCTV. “I did that. Thursday, just before closing. A portly man with a wonderful tweed waistcoat and a grief that had clearly come out in the wrong order said he couldn’t do the loops with his fingers and would I write it. I said what’s the name and he said K, just K, make it love K, and I made a joke about James Bond’s quartermaster and he didn’t get it but he laughed anyway because he wanted me to feel I hadn’t embarrassed both of us.” She flicks past the part where she burned herself because that is not the kind of detail that wants to be centre stage. “He paid cash out of a change purse, which is adorable in a man over forty if you don’t think too deeply about why, and he smelled like boiled sweets and old cigarette smoke. Hair like sheep’s wool. He said the lady liked cream because it didn’t show the dust.” She winces because she has said lady and not woman and she thinks she might be judged, and then she sees she is not.

“Did he give a name for K,” Owen asks, and her head shakes while she returns ribbon spools to a drawer that is trying to quarrel with her about how full it should be. She is writing the shape of the man in her mind and cannot find a detail that will be decisive without making him into a caricature. “I can draw his nose,” she says, and laughs because that sounds like a threat. She searches under the till for previous day’s scrap paper because Paper & Thread is run on the belief that the world will keep track of small, nice things if given chance. She produces a receipt with nothing on it except a drawn loop that might have been her hand practicing the K until it was something she would be prepared to let go of. “Sorry. That’s nothing. That’s not helpful.” Then she adds, “He held the peony like it was a baby hedgehog. I liked him for that. If he did wrong in your world, he didn’t do it on purpose.”

Outside in the blowy light you only get over the river, there is a noticeboard behind glass with fading event flyers arranging themselves into a calendar of optimism. Owen ticks through with his eyes because walls tell stories when enough of them have been used for notices. Crochet for Cancer, Wednesday nights. Mindful Parenting, first Monday. Men in Sheds, ongoing. There, between a pastel poster with a cupcake and a yoga class advertised by a woman who could hold a plank for a month, is a handbill for Clarity Coaching with Ken Wright BA (Hons), MA (PosPsych), letters like credentials that can be laid like ammunition. Find your what by finding your why, it says. Ladder your goals. Saturdays at the Quaker Meeting House, one-to-ones by appointment, be seen, be heard, be well. There is a number and a photo of a man with a smile practiced in a mirror that has been told to be honest. The initial in the name is the one that has been living in his head all morning. There are only so many K’s a town can keep in stock.

“What have you got,” Maeve asks when he returns, shaking rain off herself as if it is an opinion she didn’t ask for. He shows her Ken Wright’s face and she groans with respect. “Of course he is called Ken,” she says. “There is a very particular kind of Ken. He has a whiteboard he wheels and a marker he treats like a wand. He says content-free sentences about journeys and sees the tears as confirmation the journey has begun. Don’t make that face, Owen. I know you have recently discovered your heart is a large origami swan and you want to be kind. Ken will test you.” He tells her Katie’s description of the man with the tweed and the boiled sweets smell and they both conjure three different people from the description and none of them feels like the one. “He could be a choir master or the man who calibrates scales in chemists,” she says. “He’s either loved by a village or feared by all his grandchildren. We shouldn’t be making a pantomime. But also I would pay to watch him audition for one.”

The woman on Greenway Avenue acquires a name that fits her better than dead woman. Her name is Marion Vale and she used to file the library books under the wrong categories on purpose when de-shelving annoyed her because she liked the idea that someone might find a dictionary in Local History and be tempted to read it. She has a daughter Laura who would do anything for her mother and a son between jobs who is bad at Auntie cards and good at taking bins out without being asked. She has a friend Wendy who wears carnival pink and fills Thursday afternoons with gossip that is kinder than gossip pretends it will be. Marion has a watch that is missing and a peony that is a curiosity, and a bruise on the wrist that refuses to pick a team. Owen and Maeve sit with Laura in the little conservatory that was never quite sure why it was added and drink tea that tastes like it has been asked to make a point. “There was a man,” Laura says, as if bringing something to a table and apologising for the size. “Not a man like a story ought to have. A man like an envelope. He came two weeks ago with a leaflet. Mum said he was a very smooth person. He told her talking helps and she told him to sell his talk where the talk-hungry are.” She looks at the leaflet on the sideboard and pushes it towards them with one finger, reluctant to touch it twice. Ken Wright’s overly sincere face looks up from its gloss. The initial sits there as if it had applied to be in their afternoon and had been accepted. “He had that notepad,” Laura says, “the slim one like you have if you are trying to look like you are not taking notes but you are taking notes. He looked at Mum’s hands as if he was going to tell them to relax. She didn’t like that at all.”

By the time they reach the Quaker Meeting House the afternoon looks grey in the way a dishcloth looks grey after enthusiasm has been taken from it. The board outside says There is something of God in everyone, in careful temporary letters you can wipe off with a damp cloth if the world complains too loudly. Ken Wright arrives between one breath and the next, wearing a jacket the colour of wet cardboard and shoes that are new enough to have just a little retail shop in them still. He is shorter than his photo would like him to be and his smile has borrowed something from the way doctors smile in dramas just before giving either excellent or terrible news.

“Officers,” he says, and the word has the game-show flourish of a man who learned to include people by naming them. “Come to find your why.”

“Come to find your Ken,” Maeve says, and he does a laugh that shows the effort he is willing to make for strangers to feel charming. He is not unpleasant on purpose. He is rehearsed and that is its own kind of warning.

“We’re asking about contact with Marion Vale,” Owen says. “Two weeks ago you were in her house. We know because the universe has a habit of telling on us with bits of paper.”

Ken does his serious-man face, the one he thinks will reassure them that he keeps his heart in a responsible place. “I run a group for the bereaved,” he says, “among other things. I do workplaces and couples and grief and getting up in the morning and the midlife thirty-six-hour stare. Marion called me a twit which is a word I have a lot of time for, and I said I accept that designation, and then we talked about hedges for fifteen minutes. She asked if I was going to charge her for the hedges chat. I said no, because I’m not a bastard.” He looks at Owen as if to gauge whether bastard is the kind of word he can say in this conversation. Owen’s face does not contradict him but does not give him encouragement to add a stronger one. “I did not sell her anything,” Ken continues. “She did not want me to exist in her week.”

“Did you know she died,” Maeve asks, two beats late to stop him framing his answer to another, less solemn question. His mouth opens to do the oh no face and his forehead remembers it has muscles for that. Even if it is performance, it is conscientious performance. “I saw something on the Facebook group for the street,” he says. “I don’t do Facebook but my assistant compiles a digest because people gossip where they live. Terrible. I’m sorry. I don’t think—obviously we need to think—but I don’t think my chat about hedges did it.”

Owen finds he wants not to dislike him and then becomes suspicious of that wanting as if it is an advert trying to sell him bread he already has. “Do you know a gentleman,” he says, “of an age to have bought a small change purse and an inclination to admit it in public. Tweed waistcoat. Sheep wool hair. Smelt of boiled sweets he does not share. Bought a paper flower from a shop and asked for it to be labelled ‘Love K’.”

Ken does three small expressions to process the many details he has been handed. He is good at this; he has sat in rooms where people have thrown the contents of their day at his face and he has had to find the thread that would make them feel stitched into their own lives. “Mr. Kettle,” he says, and looks quietly proud of his memory. “He comes to my Tuesday mornings and tells me to stop calling him Mr. Kettle because it makes him feel like a black-and-white kitchen. Kevin Kettle, but nobody calls him Kevin because he is perfectly made for his surname. He does indeed wear tweed in seasons that do not require it and he has the sugar habit you have observed. He has a pocket full of barley sugar, I swear he does it because it makes him feel like a Victorian who’s allowed to take tigers on walks. He looks after a woman called Elsie who is his neighbour and who has an awful habit of falling over in shops. He is always doing love Ks because he thinks first names are intimate and last names are rude.”

“Would Mr. Kettle buy a flower for Marion Vale,” Owen asks, and Ken tilts his head like a dog who has been asked why, philosophically, fetch is relevant to the human condition. “He does gifts,” Ken says. “He is the kind of person who, when a pain happens in a radius of streets around him, puts a small object in the pain’s immediate vicinity to make it feel like the world has noticed. His ethics are fine if this is about ethics. He is a man with a key to many people’s houses and nobody has ever had the key cut back to a single because they mind. He will have done the bin for her without telling her. He will have fixed her doorbell and then told her it was a fairy. Please don’t kick him for being helpful. I know helpful can also be a mask. But with him it is not a mask that wants to be a thief.”

Maeve and Owen exchange a look that is not a decision but is the prelude to one. They will knock on Mr. Kettle’s door with biscuits because certain men need nine minutes of chat before a question will sit in the room without making them proud. They will see the barley sugars rolled into the corner of a drawer and they will see a little saucer for coins by the key stand and they will think indecently that it is nice to be right when it doesn’t cost anyone.

They go anyway to Rook & Rooke because there is a drum in Owen’s chest that plays Silas even when the orchestra has been told to pack up. The salvage yard smells of damp paint and the iron in blood and sometimes of a lost fry-up. Silas is not at the front; he never is when a polite conversation would suit everyone concerned. He is somewhere in his labyrinth of municipal chairs and radiators that wanted one more life. A boy with a face like a church step looks up from an angle grinder with the solemn intensity of someone who has just learned what an angle is. “He’s not here,” the boy says, which is nearly always true and therefore always suspicious. Owen walks farther in because there is a degree to which waiting for Silas in his own rooms is like asking a trickster to send you a postcard.

He appears with a piece of brass in one hand that looks like it came from a ship that sank for a very dramatic reason. He does a look that is almost shy and then forgets to make it into arrogance. “Have you seen my watch,” he says, pleased to revisit an old line, and Owen doesn’t give him the satisfaction of giving him the history he wants. “Do you know Ken Wright,” he asks, and Silas laughs as if asked whether he knows electricity. “He told me to breathe,” Rook says. “Imagine. Someone had to tell me to do that. I told him I like to outsource the regular jobs. He wrote the word outsized by mistake and kept it. He has a whiteboard like your colleague guesses, the quiet one with the hands who could probably make a swan out of a receipt and make the swan think about its life choices. Is he in your book. Is Ken a suspect. He’d love that. He’d word-cloud himself to death.”

“You go to his group,” Owen says. “Saturdays.”

“I go where biscuits are,” Rook says. “I go because I have an enquiring mind. He tells us to do body scans which is a very silly name for closing your eyes and noticing that your shoulders do not live at the tops of your ears. My shoulders are renting extra rooms in my skull. He told me to let them out and I told him my deposit was non-returnable.” He puts the brass on the table with the carefulness of a man who has held objects that were once valuable to someone else and cannot forget that fact however hard he tries to style it out. “You worried you cannot like a man who tells other men to breathe,” he asks, and Owen feels too seen for a second and resents it. “I am worried,” Owen says, and it is a considered sentence, “about people collecting other people’s need and spending it badly.”

“You’re a policeman,” Rook says. “You live in that economy.”

There are days when he does not entirely know why he doesn’t hit Silas Rook in the face and then remember. Hitting him would be an admission that his sentences are objects you can catch and he is not going to juggle on Silas’s stage. He says that they have a man named Kettle on their list to talk to and watches Silas’s eyebrows take the information and file it under Not Immediately Useful to Me. Rook picks imaginary fluff from his sleeve and does the thing where he flips the conversation into a joke that wants to be an exit. “You’re making peonies now,” he says. “It suits you. Something about your mouth looks less like it is holding an alarm between its teeth. I like it when men do pretty things and do not apologise for being alive while doing them. Bring one to my yard and I’ll try not to set fire to it to make a point.”

The appointment with Mr. Kettle is half an hour of happiness disguised as a lecture on grids. He has a doormat that says Not Today and a collection of Victorian Cyanide Poison warnings framed in the loo because he says it reminds him not to put the wrong thing in anyone else’s tea. He is the kind of man who calls Owen “my dear fellow” and actually means dear and fellow in some old kind way. There are sweets in every room in little pressed glass bowls that have known many Christmases and have probably survived a house move like soldiers. He proudly shows them his change purse that has a snap you cannot buy anymore, he says, unless you know a woman called Beryl who deals in these things and is likely to outlive them all. He has the need to explain why he writes Ks when he does not know if he has been accused of anything. “Kevin,” he says, and his cheeks do a flutter that is nearly a blush. “I don’t like Kevin. It has always made me feel like I am about to be called to the front of a class to spell something I already know I cannot spell. So K. Love K. It’s ridiculous at my age but also life is ridiculous at my age and therefore there is a compatibility.” He bought the peony for Marion last week, he says, because she was cross about hedges and there is no better treatment for hedge crossness than a thing that is aggressively not a hedge. He handed it to Wendy because Wendy likes to be the bringer. He has never been in Marion’s house without permission and not even then because he doesn’t like to catch people in their rooms with their mouths unbraced.

He speaks about Ken with the resigned affection of a man who has accepted a doctor for an ailment he isn’t sure he has. “He tells me I should stop collecting people’s shopping trolleys,” he says. “He says I cannot push everyone’s trolley to the coin return, and I say I can, and then the next week I bring him a tally. He is trying to be kind. He does it in a tone that reminds me of small sermons, but he does not take your money while he does it unless you give it with both hands, which I do, because I like a room where the tea is hot and nothing is thrown.” He has no beef with anyone alive, and yet he carries himself like a man who has been armed with a sense of duty since he was nine. It is hard to file that under suspect and then it is irresponsible to file it under harmless; men who seem like saucers can carry knives like anyone else.

The day does that settling down thing where the town puts on the lights it can afford and hopes the rest will make its own arrangements. The paperwork is a tide coming in behind him and Owen allows himself to be stood in it up to the knees because if you pretend there is no water it still wets you. He puts the peony from the class on the shelf above his desk where past him used to put a football scarf in winter and a postcard from a seafront showing a painted donkey. Griggs passes by, sees the flower, opens his mouth to make a remark and then closes it again because the effort of forming the remark and the probable satisfaction once said will not pay for the ugliness it will leave afterwards. He says instead that Priorswood will want a visit because the copper pipe turned out to belong to a church undergoing a re-plumb and you cannot mess with churches even if you are a pagan about plumbing. On the whiteboard someone has added Paper K in green and someone else has put a question mark next to it that is so emphatic it has probably bruised the pen nib. The station smells of the coffee that has been made strong to prove a point and a portion of chips that has vanished in the time it takes to turn a wheel. The night men filter in with faces like people who have been told the punchline and are trying to frame their day as a setup that will justify it.

At home he does a strange thing that feels like cheating on the person he was last year. He clears a space on the table that most people would consider to be already empty and lays out tissue paper in squares like siding tiles on a house he will never own. His hands have learned to do the pinching without thinking but still require him to be present, which is a luxury. He teaches himself a leaf from a drawing he can find on the internet but doesn’t because he has decided that it is possible to invent if you are willing to fail at something someone else could teach you in six minutes. The radio is a mumble in the corner and a man says the words of the day as if he is in charge of deciding what they mean. Owen makes three leaves that all look like they have been on different trees, which is fine with him because if they had agreed with each other it would have been a small lie. He puts the flower he never will give to his mother on the table with a new friend and the table does not notice, which is right, because he would like some things not to be enormous in the way that the world thinks they ought to be.

He does not sleep as a verb; he sleeps as a negotiation. His dream is a lecture hall with a craft table at the front, and he is required to stand and make peonies while explaining a case and every time he says the word motive the paper tears. He wakes in the grey that is not quite morning and goes to the window to watch the river not be about him, which is a discipline and a relief. A text from Maeve arrives with a photo of a leaflet for the Clarity group with the note: your boyfriend Ken is doing a weekend retreat. Do not attend unless you want to be told to tell your inner policeman to relax. He writes back that his inner policeman is too busy knitting and she sends an emoji that she would tell her nephew not to use.

He meets Katie again without meaning to because the town keeps its people like a handful of pebbles you think you have thrown and then find again in the pocket of an old coat. She is outside Paper & Thread chalking a sandwich board with a hand that can do italics without arrogance. She is writing, today: we are open and not in a hurry. Her hair has committed to being in the knot that it became by accident yesterday. He tells her about Marion in the edge-of-the-news way that he knows how to do now, careful to keep the details that would pull her into a room he can’t close for her. “We have a Mr. Kettle,” he says, and she brightens at the name as if she has been told a story she was already ready to enjoy. “He came in yesterday and asked me if I had a ribbon that looks like it knows how to behave itself,” she says. “I told him not a one. He bought the worst behaved ribbon I have and said excellent, that’s what I like in a person.”

If the world were the kind of world where you could smell coincidence, he would at this point have to sneeze. It is a small place. People like Ken identify the smallness and sell it back to you as intimacy. People like Silas exploit it as a map they can draw in versions that suit them. People like Mr. Kettle make it an economy of kindness. People like Marion live in it and ask it to be practical. People like Owen walk through it with heavy keys and try to keep all the doors honourably on their hinges.

At midweek there is a new event that is not dramatic in the way the newspaper likes to be fed but is the sort of thing that makes the strings on the map in the briefing room want to tug. There is a night-time taking-attempt from the back room of Paper & Thread and it is not the till, which is what you take when you are not acquainted with a person’s looking. It is the boxes of wire and the good glue gun that has a chrome bit on it as if one day it knew what it was like to be a car. The lock is prised with an intelligence that is not refined but is confident. On the floor in the mess of tissue and ribbon is a shoe print that is a half-moon of bossing from a brand that sells itself on young men believing their ankles are doing something important. The world is like that—a man will spend on ankle drama what he might not spend on lunch. Katie is shaken in the way of a person who finds the place where she keeps her sleep disturbed. She wants to tidy while talking and folds paper while worrying, which is like rain explaining itself.

“Why take wire,” Maeve asks out loud as if the wire might develop a conscience in response and arrange a return. Katie’s answer is both craft and town. “The wedding over the weekend,” she says, “the one at the rugby club with the backdrop that lights up, the lads used all my stock last-minute because the first lot went missing in the van crash. They told me I should be grateful because they paid cash, as if cash makes everything into a better story. I think someone saw me write down that I would order more and thought if I order and it arrives before I am here then this is the kind of shop that will prop its door with a broom and hope the world is good. Maybe someone wanted to try their hand at bending things. People like to play God with wire. It does the thing you want at speed, which is dangerous.”

Inside that answer is a small shape Owen turns with his mind like a coin. Wire from a craft shop is cleaner and more predictable than the scrap at Rook’s, which is a tangle of old fences and bits of bedsprings and something that once held a sign that said SLOW near a school. If he were to be a person with ambition for making a different thing that looks like a thing that ought not to exist, he would buy his wire new. He would want regularity, obedient length. He would want the cut to be clean. He does not say it because it is not yet a thought that has anywhere to sit. He logs the shoe print, he notes the lock, he tells Katie to get a camera that isn’t insulting to the future and she says she already has one and it is cheerful yellow which is a choice she has made with hope.

That evening he takes Maeve to the Ken meeting because anything done with a witness is less likely to become an anecdote with sharp teeth. The Quaker room is all the calm you would give a person if they were afraid of today. The chairs are laid in a semi-circle less because semi-circles are optimal for learning and more because the person laying them wanted to feel less like they were arranging a jury. Ken writes on his whiteboard slowly as if afraid his pen will feel used, and his words are saying nothing new and managing to be what some people need and that contradiction is chewable if you don’t mind the taste. Silas is there in the back making a face like a schoolboy and choosing not to hide from himself. Mr. Kettle is at the front with his hands on his knees and his absence of need arranged in a shape that will not frighten anyone. There is a woman who is trying not to be the crying person and a man who is too busy telling his own story in his head to hear anyone else’s. There are biscuits and the least haughty tea he has tasted in a week and a poster that says today’s you is okay. Ken says things about breath and noticing and the three-minute vacation you can give yourself if you sit in your car and listen to traffic without making any of it your fault. The part of Owen that mistrusts being told to notice things when he notices things for a living is belligerent. The part of him that has been doing pelmanism with Silas under the table for a decade relaxes anyway when someone else is allowed to say a sentence that is a soft landing. Maeve watches with the intent of a person who is going to take the piss later and then will make him bacon in the morning because she wants good outcomes.

After, when coats find their arms and chairs return to their little lines, Ken tries a question as if trying a new tie. “What do you do when you are not making sure we are not parts of a riot,” he asks Owen, and the room manages that paradoxical attention where everyone is being polite about not looking and everyone wants to hear the answer. He says, “I make paper peonies,” because there is freedom in being ridiculous on purpose and he finds that he wants to root his week in something that isn’t a filing system and a siren. The room breathes out in laughter that is not about him and he likes it for that. Silas says, “Oh good,” and Ken, to his credit, doesn’t turn it into a prompt about softness. He writes the word hobby on the board and then rubs a bit of it out absentmindedly and leaves hobb, and Owen watches the word more keenly than is sensible because it looks like a thing from a fairy story.

Back in the street the night has decided what kind of dark it wants to be and it is the hospitable one with enough lamps. Owen can feel the case putting out little roots now, bits that will either make a plant given space and time or will die in the soil and nourish other worries. He has a Mr. Kettle who is a conduit. He has a Ken who gathers and therefore knows. He has a Katie who is in the vulnerable category of person you want to be friends with your whole life. He has a Silas learning to breathe in a group and making that fact make a noise. He has a watch-shaped nothing and the faintest whisper of a bruise. He has paper, which is silly and also ought not to be dismissed because sometimes the silly is the thing that makes the room bearable enough to do the serious.

On his way home, just for the satisfaction that being in motion brings, he cuts across the bus station and the weather is doing the thing with its sleeves again, rolling them up like it means to get involved. A boy is making aimless shapes with his bike and he is the kind of boy who has invented a way of making eye contact that doesn’t risk it. It takes a second to recognise him without the posture of errands and a message, but then it is Aiden, shoes less white now, fewer sharp lines. He sees Owen and decides in an instant not to be someone else for the purposes of this conversation. “That thing the other day,” he says instead of hello, and he means the five boys and the bins and the relief disguised as shouting. “My mum said if I see you to tell you she liked that you didn’t say feral. She said a lot of people like that word too much. She says feral is a cat, not a person. She said,” and he has to push this next bit out because he is sixteen and kind and the combination burns, “she said to tell you she is a person and it was a bad day and if you see her she will not run.” Owen nods and says tell her I said sorry for the day being bad. Aiden leans on the bike like it feels like furniture he brought from home. “I got a job,” he says, which is not true, not yet, but it is an intention that is wearing boots. “At the yard. Not heavy work. Tidy work. Sorting work. The bald man said he would teach me the names of woods and I could maybe not steal them after if I know them. He’s funny. He says he’ll make a church boy of me. I don’t know what that is. Do you.” Owen thinks of Silas in the back of a Quaker room pretending to have invented breath and he laughs, and the night looks at him in a surprised way and does not report him to anyone for enjoying something.

When he gets home, because the day has not finished and it will not until he decides to let it, he takes the peony from the shelf and attaches one of the leaves he made badly and the leaf sits there like a joke that landed anyway. He writes Marion’s name in his book with care as if by writing it the right way he is paying a fee he has owed to the day. He writes Kettle, Ken, Katie, Rook, peony—class—and the act of putting the words near each other brings with it a small fizz, as if he has shaken something carbonated and now must decide whether to open it or leave it overnight to quieten. He writes watch and underlines it because watches mark you if you let them. Before sleep he texts Maeve: do not let Ken make me write my feelings on a post-it. She replies: he can’t afford the amount of post-it that would require. He goes to bed and in the hour where he usually listens to the pipes practice their rhythms, he hears, very faintly, the town, leaning into a curve and getting around it with only a small wobble, and that, for one night, is enough.

Chapter Five

By morning the river is wearing a scarf of its own breath and the town has put on its weekday face, the one with the quicker shoes. Owen stands with his coat half on and watches the rain make punctuation marks on the station’s steps, commas and ellipses that can be read as either encouragement or delay depending on the reader. Maeve arrives with coffee that has considered being coffee and decided to remain an implication; she hands it over like a conspirator and shrugs out of her hood with the affronted dignity of a cat. Griggs passes through the foyer with a folder under his arm which is the shape all his optimism takes, and says in the general direction of everyone that the pathologist’s preliminary says probably natural for Marion Vale and definitely inconvenient for the paperwork, then adds to the room at large that the watch is still a noun with no adjective and he would appreciate people going out into the world and supplying one.

They begin with the obvious because the obvious is not stupid until you have proved it is. Wendy lives in a terrace with a front garden that is more ornaments than soil, a collection of ceramic frogs that all have opinions. She wears her carnival pink in daylight the way some people carry a torch, to make dark corners belong to them, and she welcomes them in with the sort of energy that tells you she has already cried and is trying on three substitutes to see which will keep the day aloft. The house is middle-of-the-week tidy, which is to say the dishes are done and the cushions are behaving but nobody has performed theatre for strangers. She talks without being asked for a bit because silence is a muscle you have to warm up for, and when she is ready she says she took the peony last Thursday because it looked like luxury you could put your thumb through, and she put it on the mantel and made a joke about it being the one flower Marion would never kill by forgetting water. She says Marion told her off for the ribbon being a bit much and then stroked the ribbon with two fingers like a person remembering a skirt she once had that swished.

They do the hour with Wendy in a way that makes time behave. She puts two mugs out and adds sugar without asking because it is easier to be told off for generosity than to anticipate the needs of strangers, and she sits and tries to picture Thursday in a way that will please them. She remembers the weather being the kind that cannot commit and the delivery man frustrated by his own existence and Marion’s mouth set in a line that meant the council had annoyed her into eloquence. She does not remember the watch coming off because she never saw the watch off in ten years of Thursdays, which is a fact that hangs in the room like a polite ghost. There was a man at the door just before she left, she says, and then grimaces because that has the shape of plot when she is only telling them about a man who wanted to clear gutters and spoke as if he wanted to be believed as a career. He had a jacket in that particular hi-vis that looks tired even when new, and he had a clipboard you could have made at home. She told him she did the gutters personally up a ladder in heels and he said she was a card, and she said what kind of card, and he did not have the wit to answer, and she closed the door on his usefulness. It was ten to four, ish, because she had to pick up her granddaughter at four and she is a woman who watches the edges of hours.

They check the street’s camera as if asking a wall to present a memory and the wall tries, offering them a slice of world with the colour taken down a notch. There is a van that could be any van and a man who could be a hundred men, the sort of shape that the universe produces when it is tired of people and wants only silhouettes. He walks quickly because walking slowly invites chat, and his hood is up not because of weather but because anonymity is a habit. They can’t see his face and they can’t see his clipboard and still a feeling moves across both of them at the same time, the feeling you get when life repeats itself in little, irritating ways. Halcon had a man with a clipboard who knew the sound a tin of meter coins makes even through a cupboard door and had a way of being as domesticated as a wolf can look through glass.

On the way back they stop in a shop that deals in things the previous generation used to call valuables and now we have learned to call sentimental because only one of those names pays. The pawnbroker has glasses that have seen everything and refuse to be impressed by it twice, and he leans on the counter and makes them a world-weary cup of tea without offering milk because he has learned to be a neutral host. The description of Marion’s watch is too precise to be interesting—it is the kind of watch that tells the time and disapproves of novelty—and he listens like a man who likes a story even if he cannot sell it. He shakes his head and then says a thing that is not no, not exactly; a man brought in a watch yesterday that had a back engraved, and pawnbrokers do not love engraved things because they carry too much biography. The man made a face when he was told the engraving made it a problem of belonging, and the man had the particular angry carefulness of someone who wants to appear not angry. He had a beard that wished it was an argument and a jacket that once belonged to a better man. He gave the name Dave because of course he did and left the watch in a pocket as if it was the sort of pocket that doesn’t make things more complicated the longer they stay.

They do the rounds of the scrap-yards and the small shops where cash still behaves like a cousin you can borrow things from, and the watch has not presented itself like a dog that knows its own name. It is an absence that keeps being itself. On a side street just past the barbers that calls itself a lounge, Maeve slows to look at a poster for Chair Yoga with a woman sitting in a chair like a person who has decided elegance can compromise if it wants to. “She teaches on Thursdays,” she says, and she points with her chin because her hands are busy with a thought. “The hall two minutes from Greenway. If Marion wasn’t for Ken with his whiteboard she might have been for a woman who offers to move with your bones rather than against them.” It is nothing more than weather until it is something else, and they put it on a mental list because their physical lists already insist they are at capacity.

Back at Paper & Thread, the aftershock of the attempted break-in is still in the room like someone’s breath, a temperature change and an untucked corner. Katie has done the thing a certain kind of person does when shaken by the way the world insists on being itself; she has arranged everything more perfectly than yesterday, as if kindness to objects can talk the air out of a bad mood. The lock is a new lock because she has a friend who is a locksmith or is in love with one, and the camera at the back is now a little yellow bird with a black pupil, brighter than anything else in the alley. She does not ask for an update on Marion because she is afraid that an update turns you into the sort of person who is entitled to one, and that is not who she wants to be. She asks instead about the shoe print, and when they tell her it is a brand of trainer that smells of lunchtime fights and birthday money, she nods because she knows it was a child-man and she knows how children wear menace like an oversized coat.

Owen kneels and fixes the cable run for the camera with the kind of carefulness he gives to everyday things he respects and sometimes forgets to respect. He asks about the order that went missing for the rugby club and she snorts and says the lads wanted to build a backdrop that made the room forget what it was, and when one of them knocked her card machine off the counter with his enormous romance she made them pay in notes. He asks without asking if anyone new has been interested in wire and she says yes, a man with not a lot of hair and an interest in his own elbows came in two days ago and asked how much wire it would take to make a forest, which is the kind of thing men who want to test you say, and she said depends on your trees. He didn’t buy anything because he was there to learn how to speak her language and left with three words and a picture of the till in his head. It is not Silas because Katie would have said Silas; she is a woman who uses names like stepping stones when she crosses a stream.

In the afternoon they sit at their hot desk purgatory and eat things that insist they were food based on paperwork alone. The pathologist rings to say the bruise on the wrist is a shy thing that cannot quite decide what it wants to be when it grows up. It is small and oblong and in the place where watch straps pinch if a hand is snatched without courtesy, which is not proof but is a story a person can tell themselves about a last carefulness that became an indignity. He says there is nothing of hand on mouth and nothing of knee in a bad place and nothing that demands anyone be led away for a dramatic conversation with the custody desk. He says also that hearts are manufactories and they stop without warning when components get old under fluorescent lights, and that is not poetry and not not-poetry either.

They go and see Chair Yoga because the day has decided to be themed. The hall smells like tea and dust as if it has been faithful to an era longer than any of its users, and a row of women in cardigans that resemble clouds are doing very small things with their spines while a voice tells them they are doing magnificently. The instructor is younger than the women and older than the girls who will replace her, and she has the patience of someone who has watched people be furious with their own backs and forgiven them for it. She remembers Marion because Marion said the chair was a friend who had become boring and she was trying to be kind to a boring friend. She remembers Marion wearing the watch and tapping its face as if intimidating time into agreeing to behave, and she remembers no gutters man in that hour because the hall has a noticeboard where such men leave their leaflets, and she personally rips them down and gives them to the school for cutting out because the children do not care for scams yet. She knows Wendy because of course she does and she says of Wendy that she is a good weather system in a cold room.

At the Meeting House Ken is holding a one-to-one with a man who looks like a wardrobe whose shelves are overloaded, and he catches Owen’s eye in the way of someone who would like to be seen to be helpful. They speak alleys and gutters with the shorthand of two people who have become temporary colleagues in a theatre where neither of them owns the stage. Ken tells him that three of his old ladies have had visitors lately with talk of water damage that is less about water and more about entering. He says he wrote down a plate number badly because he does his best thinking in loops and straight lines frighten him, and he offers the paper in his pocket that has two possible eights and a five that could be an S. There’s a small satisfaction in being the recipient of someone else’s care, even if it is chaotic care, and Owen takes the paper as if it is a guinea pig.

Silas is not at the yard and not in the places where he likes to be seen being not, and when Owen does catch him he is on the river path doing nothing with his arms, which for Silas is a performance. They walk side by side as if it had been arranged and avoid looking like they are avoiding the looking. Owen mentions the gutter men and Rook sucks his teeth because he hates amateurs who think a disguise is a fluorescent jacket. He says there is a cousin-cousin with a van who does legitimate roof work and an illegitimate tendency to let his friends borrow credibility in exchange for forever owing him sausages. He says he will ask without making it look like a policeman asked through him and he will report back whether there is any love in that lineage. He says the thing about watches is not time, it is that they are small and gold-looking and a certain kind of boy thinks that makes them coins with faces. He says he will return to Ken to be told to slow down his jaw and he will consider chewing each mouthful for a county-approved number of times and he will probably lie and reduce it by three.

The pawnshop rings just before five and the man with the glasses that do not get excited twice says the beard has returned and is now calling itself Gary because Dave is a name that gets used up quickly in these types. He says the watch is now in a different pocket and the beard has learned to say his girlfriend gave it to him, which is a sentence that is supposed to plug moral holes and somehow never once has. They go and the beard is the sort of beard that has become a shelter for a face that wants to be older, and the man attached to it has the twitchy kindness of a person who will apologise even when he has been robbed. He says he found the watch under a bench in Goodlands Park while throwing a ball for a dog with one ear and he says this too quickly for belief to be an option. He introduces the dog’s name as if that helps and the dog is called Nigel, which is either a lie so grand it deserves applause or proof there is a God of small comic touches.
